At $31 C per night mid-week in early December including taxes it was a bargain. If you book through Travelocity the rate is about $15 less than on the Arizona Charlie web site. A bit of plumbing noise from other rooms, and in the morning the cleaning staff were noisy outside on the open corridors. Sign up for their Ultimate Rewards card on the internet before you go and you can get discounts and a free buffet after only a bit of play. The buffet was barely adequate, but for the price was OK.

Oct 11 2006 	Great!	Just returned from another great trip to Vegas. I had stayed at the other Arizona Charlie's location on Decatur a couple of years back and it was great, so I figured I couldn't go wrong with the Boulder location. I am a member of their Ultimate Rewards club (the players club for both Arizona Charlie's locations as well as the Stratosphere) and responded to a direct offer I had received from them which gave me an upgraded suite for the price of a standard room.Check-in was very rapid and I was especially appreciative of the check-in clerk, Elenora. I was having a problem with my debit card - it turned out the company had put a temporary block on it for suspicion of identity theft! Fortunately I got it all straightened out, and Elenora swiped that card about 10 different times over the course of an hour without even frowning. That takes alot of patience - you don't often see much of that in the customer service industry anymore. Thanks again, Elenora!The property differs slightly from the Decatur location as all of the corridors and buildings are outside vs. being enclosed. The decor of the rooms is a little more Mediterranean vs. southwestern, as the Decatur location is. The suite (I believe it was a Standard King Suite) was very spacious, two televisions, extra cold air conditioner, very good water pressure, and lots of closet space. The casino was great as always and the Sourdough Cafe was teriffic. Be sure to check out the $2.99 Steak and Egg special, it's the best you'll ever had and has won several awards in Las Vegas magazines.Overall, a teriffic stay and I'd recommend it to everyone. Remember, you won't get the glitz and glamour of the Strip in some of these off-strip casino hotels, but it's been proven that places like these are far superior in customer service and higher casino payouts. The room prices and friendly employees can't be beat. Give it a try!

Jun 30 2006	Terrible	Following is a list of overall impressions:1) The facade is under construction, making it difficult to get around the front of the hotel/casino. Trucks and workers often impeded clientele traffic.2) We had a heck of a time finding the hotel check in desk. Only one sign hinted at its location, then we finally had to ask the valet guy.3) Overall, the exterior is filthy. The sidewalks are ugly with air conditioning, gum and grime stains. Some portions of the exterior were repainted, with overspray on the walkways (no tarps used), The walls and air conditioning units were grimy.4) We booked a "deluxe" suite with a king bed. There's one big, stark room with a tiny TV in the amoir. Grimy old carpet and dingy walls greeted us. The "ball/hook" door lock was broken off. The bedroom had another tiny TV/amoir, with a fair mattress, and the sink (single) RIGHT NEXT to the bed. The pillows were small, and the linens were stingy (only two bath, hand and wash towels).5) We called the front desk to get some additional pillows around 6PM, and no one ever came. When we called again to inquire, they said "housekeeping" was hard to reach. No one ever called back, and we never got our pillows.6) The bathroom fan did not work. Use your imagination after an evening out eating.7) Service at the Sourdough cafe was abysmally slow. Even after the restaurant manager visited our table to "check" on us, our meals took another 10 minutes to arrive.Bottom line, this place is the WORST hotel I've visited in over 10 years (Motel 6 does a better job), and I travel extensively. We felt unsafe walking the grounds gazing upon what looked like gang bangers. Avoid this place at all cost.

Jun 9 2006	AZ Charlies Boulder we will be back Next Year	This is only our 2nd annual trip to Las Vegas (Mom, Aunt and I). First hotel we stayed at, was AWFUL. So yes Arizona Charlies Boulder was a welcome step up. We had a nice deluxe room which was plenty big enough for us. We loved that the sink and mirror are separate from the shower. Since 3 women trying to get ready at once can be a scary thing. We had an excellent spot, parked right next to elevator and went right up to our room. Great view of the Pool which was nice the one day we got a chance to get in. We ate at the Buffet and the Sourdough Cafe, must say my preference was the Cafe, not the Buffet. Our first impression was not the best because the check in lady had NO Personality but every staff member during our stay after was very friendly, helpful and had a smile for us. You definitely need a car if you are staying here and wanting to go to the Strip or anywhere else. The only downside we did discover was the carpet was stained in some places but the room and bathroom itself looked clean and maintained. We are already planning our 3rd trip and Arizona Charlie's Boulder (East) will definitely be on our list to stay at. For the price and the location, it is a great deal...After reading all the reviews here, I was abit afraid but for the price for 3 of us, it couldn't be beat and thought OK lets do it. I am glad I didn't let the mixed reviews detour me from booking a room and staying here. Also, lastly, the air conditioner in our room worked great which is a big must have.

Apr 11 2006 	Not Great But not THAT bad	We stayed here only because it was the only room we could find when my BF had to attend a convention on last minute notice. Almost all the rooms were sold out in Las Vegas for the days of the convention. The few that were available were going for $400 plus, so this seemed like a good deal for $39 (through hotwire) a night during a busy convention week. We stayed Tuesday-Friday.LOCATIONThis is on Boulder Highway, far off the strip, and they do not have shuttle service to the strip. We had a car, so location wasn't that big of deal, but don't stay here unless you have a car. Boulder Station and Sam's Town are on either side (long walk or short drive).CHECK-INWe checked in about 11:30 AM. The clerk first told us they were completely booked, and all we could get was a double room, and no rooms were ready yet. We slipped her a $20 and she found a King/double smoking suite that was ready for check-in.Note that the front of the hotel is under construction, so you need to go through the casino entrance and check in there.ROOMThe room was barely adequate, but can't really complain for the price we got. First, the good. It was spacious. It was close to the pool, but looked out on the parking lot and the 7-11 next door, but was pretty quiet with little road noise. Fairly clean, with a stain here and there on the carpet. Also the windows open up, which is nice for fresh air and a breeze. It had two rooms. A large front room with a double bed w/end table, sofa w/end table, coffee table, armoire with drawers, and small tv (reception was clear for us, but only 8 channels, no HBO, etc. you could order movies.) The second room was a bit tight with a King bed, a corner unit with another small tv, and a sink stand. It also had a large walk-in closet. I found the bed to be fairly hard, and the pillows were very uncomfortable. The bathroom was tiny with a toilet, and a tub/shower combo. It was dingy and old with some mildew in the tile caulking. Shower pressure was ok, but not great. Shampoo and lotion for products.Be aware that the rooms have no amenities except for an alarm clock. There is no hairdryer, iron, ironing board (although i guess you can request them, although they don't make this known, but i did see one housekeeper removing one from a room), coffee maker, fridge or microwave. There is only dial-up internet access, with a 75 cent per connection fee. Also, there was only one ice maker that I could find and it was at the opposite end of the complex, there was no ice maker near the pop machine at our end. THE GROUNDSThe units all surround and open up to a courtyard. There is landscaping and paths to the casino, with a courtyard sitting area toward the casino end of the courtyard, a fountain in the middle area, and a pool area w/hot tub at the far end. There is always security around on bikes, so the grounds seemed safe.We used the pool twice and it was very uncrowded considering the place was full. They have lots of deck chairs that you can use in the sun or in a shaded area they have. The hot tub wasn't very hot, but was ok. (I noticed the reviewer below said there was no pool, but I think she must have been in the wrong area of the courtyard, because there most definitely is a pool).CASINOWe were in the unit farthest away from the Casino, but I didn't find the walk through the courtyard that long to get there; I have walked farther to get to the casino in large strip hotels. The casino was fairly small by las vegas standards. But gaming is cheap and it was never super crowded. Video Poker makes up the majority of the machines. There aren't that many tables, but I rarely saw them all full. We won some, and were up a couple hundred on our second day there, but managed to lose most of our gambling money by the end. Cocktail service was good and friendly. Lots of locals seemed to game here, and they were all friendly and fun.RESTAURANTSThere is the Wild West Buffet, The Sourdough Cafe, The Yukon Grille Steakhouse, and a deli for sandwiches and fast-food type stuff. The prices for food are extremely reasonable, and friendly service.We ate at the Sourdough Cafe for breakfast several times and a couple other meals. The ham and egg special for $2.79 is huge. They also had a steak and egg special for $2.99, the steak was a little tough, but had good flavor. My bf's favorite was the chicken fried steak and mashed potatoes he had one night for $4.99.We also tried the Yukon Grille Steakhouse one night, it was reasonable, but underwhelming. I had the small filet medium rare, which was overcooked and tasteless, and my bf had prime rib, which he didn't enjoy at all (I have a feeling you could do the prime rib in the studio cafe for $7.99 and would get the same thing). Each entree was about $18. With a bottle of wine, salads, two entrees, and a shared dessert, the total was only $75, but I would rather spend more for really good steak. Overall, I wouldn't stay here again unless circumstances required it. But if you are doing las vegas on a tight budget, it is not a bad value for your money.

Mar 17 2006 	RUN FOR THE HILLS	Please do not stay here.I live in Minnesota and my sister is in California. I am getting married in Vegas this April and found it just a little too difficult to plan EVERYTHING with out seeing anything. My sister and I went to Vegas to check out this hotel and the wedding location. This hotel was recommended to my by a friend. I was told it was great for he money. My ENTIRE family is planning to attend the wedding obviously including my mother in a WC. Now on to the bad stuff.First of all the hotel was under construction. The front of the building was missing! You couldn't even figure out where to park to check in. Valet was no help at all. Check in was another story but it took way too long. One of our first observations was that the hotel was NOT connected to the casino which is something we definitely did not want. Once inside it's your typical casino but SO SMOKEY, and Im a smoker!!! I could hardly stand it. Our room also smelled so bad. In the middle of the night it smelled like somebody was smoking right in our room. Keep in mind I had already booked 30 rooms for my wedding in April. As we are on our way to the room we noticed there was concrete where the pool was supposed to be. We did not feel that this hotel had adequate accommodations for people in WC. There was an elevator but all the buttons were broken and I really do not think it was large enough to hold a WC, luggage, and another person. This was by far the most unacceptable situations. We try to make the best of it, for the night.Do not believe the pictures on the website. No pool. There is a total of 9 tables and 1 roulette table. One the website it looks like the tables go on for miles. If you like to play tables keep this in mind.The Next MorningWe realize there is no coffee pot, no ironing board! Apparently you have to special order them. We I highly doubt they have 30 WORKING coffee pots and ironing boards at there hotel.We have an appt at 11 to pick out my flowers. After showering in a tub that made you feel that you 100lb body was going to break through the floor we were ready to dry our hair. The outlet blew up our hair dryer!!! We had to run to a Big Lots with wet hair to buy a new hair dryer. Can you imagine if that happened to me on my wedding day?Needless to say we checked out that morning with nowhere to stay. It did not feel safe. Everyone would have to rent a car as there is no airport shuttle or strip shuttle. It did not look like my mom could get around easy and it was NO place for kids. I would never lay down my baby niece on the bed with a fear she would be poked with a needle. YES, it was that bad. It was a step up from a crack house.Luckily the wedding location was beautiful, Kudos Rainbow Gardens and Thank you to Ron at Bloomers for suggesting the hotel we are now all staying at Palace Station.

Jan 3 2006	I love Arizona Charlie!!	The only thing I found wrong with this hotel was the distance to the Strip. Sep 20 2005	Better than I expected	My husband, daughter and I stayed at Arizona Charlie's Boulder Hotel and Casino September 4th, for 1 night. Our flight arrived very late Sunday night and we needed an inexpensive place to stay. I was very skeptical due to the reviews that I have read, but we decided to take a chance. I booked the room on the AC website, $49.00 for a Deluxe Suite King/Double. The hotel is undergoing rennovation on the outside. The room we received was very clean, but in need of an upgrade. The front room had a double bed, TV, and sitting area with a sofa. The bedroom had a King size bed and another TV,which was a bonus. The bathroom was small, clean but did have old fixtures. The hotel is more like a motel setting, the rooms could not be reached through the casino, all on the outside as best as I could tell. Check in was very quick but, the lady at the front desk did advise us to make sure we checked out by 11:00 AM. The beds were comfortable and there was not alot of noise. I was concened that there would be alot of noisy people and car doors slamming with the rooms facing the outside. Check out was easy and since we prepaid there was not a hassle. We were pleasatly surprised and got a good deal for the money.

Sep 1 2005	Perfectly nice motel	I just returned from a 1-night stay at AZ Charlie's Boulder. I was a little worried after reading some postings for this, but I had a nice experience. I arrived before check-in -- around 11:30 am -- but the clerk was nice enough to find me a clean room -- and by the pool, which I requested. The room was basic - 2 beds, bathroom with noisy fan, vanity/sink area, TV, table & chairs. Plenty of hangers in the closet area too. The property's kind of like an apartment complex -- lots of units and a pool area in the middle. I spent about an hour by the pool and, besides being open to guests only, I saw a bike security man ride by at least 3 times. Makes you feel safe. I ate at the breakfast buffet -- no complaints for $4.60. I got my fruit, coffee, juice, eggs and oatmeal. They even have an omelet station. And let's not forget, Charlie's is CHEAP. I would stay there again. It's very convenient to be able to check in and out very quickly, unlike the huge hotels with long lines.

Jul 14 2005	What the hell!!!!!!	Paid $49.99 for a deluxe,completely reurbished suite.Yes - probably 1933!What a dive.Checked out after 6 hours and went to Sunset Station as all others were full -weekend.That was about 2000% better.Give this place a very wide berth - lurking in those carpets and linen are bacteria that Grissom on CSI could spend a lifetime studying.The only place worse than this must be a Turkish prison.Their buffet is worse than the throwaways in the overflowing dumpsters outside.

Apr 29 2005	Nice off-strip hotel w/Casino close to transportation etc.	We stayed most recently at Arizona Charlie's Boulder in mid-January 2005. The property has standard rooms as well as mini suites. The property underwent a rennovation in 2004 and the rooms are nice, new southwest pastel decor, new furnishings, the bathrooms had tile or marbl-ey type counters.We've stayed in both. The standard rooms are what you'd expect - two beds, bathroom, TV, side chars and table, no coffeemakers or mini fridges. The suites we have stayed in have two rooms, with a door in between, 1 bed in each room, as well as 1 TV in each room. There is only 1 bathroom in the suites we have stayed in.ACB rooms are spread out on the property in 6 or 7 separate buildings. The higher the number of the building, the closer the building is to the casino. There is a pool and spa as well as a guest Laundromat. All of the rooms face open air corridors. It's never been a problem for us, but you need to note that if someone wanted to, they could walk off the street and up to anyone's room door. Again we've never had a problem; there is ample security and a bike patrol.ACB is on Boulder Highway and it lies between Sam's Town and Boulder Station. We've walked to Sam's Town from there, but Boulder looks a little far. There's a 7-11 next to the hotel and a gas station/convenience store across the street as well as a Wells Fargo Branch. A couple of minute's drive in either direction will bring you to various fast food places, drug stores and supermarkets.There is a small casino with a 24-hour Bingo parlor (that's why we go there), a standard 24-hour coffee shop, a buffet that's small but surprisingly good, and a higher-end steakhouse that we've never been to. Sometimes the hotel runs a shuttle service to other properties, ask when you get to the hotel.The staff is so-so, they can be friendly, but they've also been brusque especially at check-in. Cocktail servers, waitstaff, etc. are always nice.All in all, if you want to have a chance to gamble and have a decent room without the crowds, this is the place to be.

Feb 22 2005	Mixed Feelings	We stayed at this hotel Feb 18-21, 2005 and paid a hefty $60/night. This was, however, the cheapest we could find over a holiday weekend in Vegas. First the good points: We stayed 3 people (1 couple and 1 single) and the room set-up was great. The room has plenty of room for lots of people -- it has 2 rooms a bed in each and a couch. With an air mattress you could easily sleep 6. Beware of the beds, though -- calling htem even a double is being generous.Now the bad -- big time electrical issues!! Every time we turned on the light in the bathroom, we got zapped -- and not just a small zap! Our room only got made up once in 3 days -- despite calls to the front desk and they never did send anyone to fix the electrical issue.If you don't have a car, forget it. This is a good 20 minute drive from the strip with traffic and no shuttle is available. Hated the lunch buffet -- it was terrible. The casino is almost all slots. Not sure if we'll stay there again. Pay the extra money and go somewhere else.

Jul 17 2004	You Get What You Pay For	We booked Arizona Charlie's because of the special room rate of $29.00. So for that price we were willing to be happy with whatever we got. However, our stay was somewhat disappointing. It would have been okay in an average city, but not for Las Vegas. First of all, potential visitors should know that the rooms are nice enough but they have no amenities. By that I mean, the room we stayed in had no hair blowdryer, about 8 channels on the tv, only two towels, and a noisy air conditioner. We asked for a toothbrush from the front desk and were told we would have to buy one in the gift shop. The bathroom was smaller than average and had a very loud ventilation fan. The rooms are in separate buildings away from the casino so you have a somewhat lenghy walk to get to the casino. (Not that lengthy walks are unusual in Vegas). The casino is relatively small and the odor of cigarrette smoke is quite obvious. (An odor which tainted all of our clothes). There is no shuttle service to or from the airport or strip. The pool is small. They have three beautiful outdoor fountains in an outdoor courtyard but they were sitting dry and idle.We booked our rooms online and did not know until we checked in that there was an additional $2.50/night energy charge AND a $35 deposit (which is returned if you don't incur any additional charges during your stay.) Basically the ONLY reason you should want to even visit Arizona Charlie's East is for the food. The quality and pricing is unmatched anywhere in Vegas!! My advice is to stay somewhere else, but drive over to Charlie's for the meals!

Dec 1 2007 	Not a bad option near the Strip	I chose the Best Western McCarran as it was reasonably priced (for a Saturday night), and had free shuttles to the airport & the Strip.Both of the shuttles work on a 'request' basis, whereby you need to call and let them know that you need a pick-up. Nov 5 2007 	Airport Shuttle Issues and Rude front desk staff	My recent stay at this hotel was a big disappointment. Jul 2 2004	Good Inexpensive but you should have a car to stay here	We stayed at the McCarran Inn upon our arrival in Las Vegas (we were on our way to Bryce Canyon National Park in Utah and NOT remaining in Vegas for a long visit) On a Saturday night there are no cheap, good rooms in Las Vegas close to the airport (our plane landed at near midnight on Saturday night at the beginning of June 2004). This was the least expensive place we could find -- at $71 a night. I was expecting a flea bag motel -- instead it was very nice and clean, comfortable and had a great free breakfast buffet (juice, coffee, milk, cereal-- including instant hot oatmeal, muffins, danish,toast,fresh fruit and peanut butter packets. The only drawback is (if you are staying to see Vegas for a while) -- you need to have a car because the motel's location is away from the Strip and the Casinos. But everyone should know that if you have a car you can drive to the free lots at any of the big hotels (the Luxor is a good place to park and walk), and tour the Strip as late as you want. This makes the McCarran Inn a great bargain. I hate the long walk in and out of those huge casino hotels -- at this motel you are out and into your car in a minute instead of struggling across the casino floor with your luggage or if you forgot something in your room (it can take a half hour to get to your room and back outside in one of those huge hotels). I know some people love to stay in the lavish casinos (and there are some great package-deal bargain rooms during the week) -- but some people,like us,only needed a nice,clean,safe place to sleep on their way to a glorious week out in the wilds of Utah. In that case -- this MacCarran Inn is a really good choice. I hope this information was helpful for any of you planning a trip to Bryce and Zion with a late flight into Vegas.

Elegant and Excellent Customer Service	Loved the room. Up on the 42nd floor facing the Bellagio's Fountain (loved the fountains at night...beautiful). Got a call from the desk checking to see if we loved the room. My cousin also got a nice gift for her birthday which was in a few days. TV in the bathroom with a jacuzzi. Very nice.The buffet was lovely and the food was very well prepared and tasty.

Great Location Good Stay	We really enjoyed our Thursday - Sunday stay at Caesar's. We booked for the Forum Tower and were "upgraded" to a bigger jacuzzi room in the Palace Tower. Overall, we had a good stay. Our room was spacious, well-appointed, comfortable and clean. It was a bit of a walk to get to everything (except the pool), but that's Vegas. The pool was great and we really enjoyed the jacuzzi tub. Check in and check out were smooth and professional.Caesar's is one of the best locations on the strip and we definitely took advantage of staying here.

Can't Go Wrong	Caesars doesn't really need much comments. It lives up to everything. Location is definitely good. Nothing really bad about my stay. They ran out of double rooms in the tower we had an upgraded us to a more expensive room that had two double beds without a hassle. Even if the tables are too expensive, you can walk across the street to Bill's Gambling Hall and O'Sheas to get some of the more cheap spots.

Great Location and Pool	My Maids of Honor took me there as a surprise for my bachelorette party and it truly was a blast! We upgraded the room for a small fee (it was off season) and it was the coolest room I have ever stayed in. It was very clean and our view was spectacular. The resort location truly is the best. We were right in the middle of everything which allowed us to walk everywhere. If you like to party make sure to check out Pure. Show proof that you are staying in the hotel and they should let you in without paying a cover (This is what we did). The downfall to the hotel is the food they serve in the food court is just awful. Also, a drink by the pool and room service is extremely expensive. For a normal sized margarita by the pool was $20! So get ready to splurge!

Roman Tower - As dirty as Rome	This was our first stay at the Caesars Palace. Having stayed at other upscale hotels in Vegas like the Mandalay Bay, the Venetian, Paris, and Luxor, I expected to get at least the same type of room if not better at the Caesars. Boy was I wrong? We stayed in the Roman Tower on the 14th Floor and all I can say was that Motel 6s I've stayed at during my younger days were cleaner and more up to date.First of all, the TV was a tiny 20" Tube sitting in a cabinet that had to be at least 20 feet away from our bed due to the weird L shape of our room. There was no real closet in the room, the safe was awkwardly sitting on the floor in one corner looking like someone could just pick up the whole thing and walk away. Furthermore, one of the light bulbs in the recess lights right above our bed was missing and the entire socket appeared to be covered with what looked like mold. The bathroom was extremely old, with cracks on the vanity and mildew looking stains on the walls.... disgusting!The room was EXTREMELY NOISY. Every time one of our neighbors flushed the toilet, ran the sink, or took a shower, there was a sound of water running through the pipes that was so loud in our room, we couldn't hear each other talking. I'm not exaggerating, it was THAT loud.We only found the hair dryer on the last day when checking out. It was hidden a lower drawer below the TV. Why it would be there I have no idea.In any case, if staying at the Caesars, make sure it's not the Roman Tower. I don't know what their other Towers are like but I'm hoping they're better than this dump.

Great place to stay - I plan on being back if they comp me again	We stayed at Caesars Nov 22 thru 27th, 2009. Our first time staying at Caesars and we had gotten comped for all five nights (keep in mind this is a slow time for Vegas), because of our play and stay at other Harrah properties. Check in was about 20 mins, we had a comped room in the forum tower, I did the $50.00 tip and got us upgraded to the Augustus tower with a view of the bellogio fountains. We definately recommend this tower, rooms are awesome. We did not eat at Ceasars, we have other favorites around town. We bring our own water/coffee heater with cappicino when we go to vegas with cereal and pick up our water/pop/milk at Walgreens or the ABC store at Planet Hollywood with a collapsible cooler along. We highly recommend you go on line and google "floor plans for vegas casinos". Knowing your hotel and casino before you get to vegas will save a lot on foot power. Yes we did come home a winner, just remember always play where the people are. The most people were in the forum casino playing the pennies, just keep in mind you can play up to $5.00 a spin on the pennies.

Great Stay!!!!	Stayed at Caesars from Nov 23 -27.After reading some of the reviews for the hotel we were a bit leary about the stay. We arrived early and went to diamond check in and to our surprise there was no waiting. Check in took about 10 minutes. Was given a great room in the Forum Tower. Large room with a comfy king bed and the bathroom was very large as well. Staff was great. Third night there housekeeping removed robes and towels from the bathroom and forgot to replenish. This was quickly fixed with one phone call, Plus they gave us a $25 comp to our room for the hassel. Gaming was great at Caesars. First night I hit a $2100 jackpot. Actually left LV with money in our pockets! Food was a bit pricey but worth it. Bradley Ogden is a must. Food was GREAT! Buffet was not as good as the Rio but still good ( lots to choose from). Forum shops have a lot of variety. They do need more benches for those of us who need to stop and take a breather along the way. We enjoyed our stay at Ceasars and will be returning again next year. For those who did not have a good experience. Well this is vegas and everything is a "gamble" out here even the hotels.

Great place but I doubt if we would stay again	we have just returned from a week staying at Ceasars. The place is absolutely magnificent but HUGE - we requested the Augustus Tower as we had read that it was the closest tower to check in - THANK GOODNESS WE DID !!! by the time we checked in - mind you it took about an hour and there were only 5 of us in line at the time. The walk to the elevator to our tower was bad enough, but watching the people lugging their suitcases through the casino trying to find their way to their accomodaton was rediculous. You need a GPS system just to find your way through Ceasars. In my opinion its just TOO BIG and not very well set out - things are just too hard to find and there are a million ways you can go to find them. The rooms were fantastic - clean and modern - One thing though as a lot of other people have pointed out DO NOT TOUCH OR MOVE ANYTHING IN THE MINI BAR/FRIDGE - it is all on a sensor system and even if you move something it goes onto your account. Also we were told not to put any of our drinks or anything else we buy in the fridge, but we can hire a mini fridge - they do this for you at a charge of $30.oo per day MY GOD HO REDICULOUS.... we spent a lot of time eating and gambling elsewhere as we found that a lot of the other places had better eating places and the atmosphere was a lot friendlier and relaxed. We will be returning to Vegas within the next 12 months and while it was a magnificent place to the eye - we will be staying elsewhere - as we looked into a few other places offering the same great location/with better customer service and a lot cheaper rates.

wheres the ice!!!!!!	arrived at ceasers on wednesday the 25, 09 and stayed at the centurian tower it was not what i expected. I like to have a drink when i get to a new place unpack and unwind well there was no ice bucket i call room service and they said no ice avaiable in the entire tower they bring it up from the basement to your room i called twice i thought they got lost i said ill go down and get it but they were onthere way sure enough there my bucket of ice 1 hour later no refer in the room no coffee pot its just not what i exspected from ceasers never stayed there befor never will again 23 inch pioneer tv give me a break i really like the forum shops though get a ice cream cone 13 dollars a scoop i licked it really slow what a joke its just not the same out there any more no comps no ICE!!!!!

Caesars VERY overrated	Paid $206 (including tax) for a deluxe room at caesars on lasvegas.com for 1 night on 11/26/09. The price was fair in my opinion for what i was SUPPOSED to get which was a room in the AUGUSTUS tower with 2 queen beds. The day before i was supposed to arrive i got an email stating that my flight would arrive 3hrs earlier than first projected, so i called caesars to ask if i coulf possibly check in early, "shouldn't be a problem, happens all the time", she said. So i arrived approx 1130 am thursday, and as im pulling in to the VALET there is a sign that reads " VALET FULL. please self park". So as im about to backup and find the "self park" a parking employee informs me that "if your checking in that valet should not be a problem", that they only put out that sign to "detour locals, and non hotel guests". So i proceed to the valet, where i promptly let them know im checking in. Once inside i proceed to the hotel guest check-in. Upon arriving to the line im met by a CP employee who is telling everyone that "early check-in doesnt start until 1pm", so i tell her that ive already contacted the hotel and they know i will be arriving early. She wants none of it! Tells me to go check my bags at bell station and to come back at 1. So i proceed to walk about 50ft away to some sofas and wait. About 15mins later she disappears so i take the opportunity to jump in the line.. What do you know they have some rooms available!! Gee imagine that! The man at the desk informs me "im upgrading your room for free".. Ok now im starting to forget about everything and warm-up to this place. After informing me that they would charge an additional $200 on my debit card for "incidentals", he informs me that im staying in the PALACE TOWER room 1038. COOL. So instead of walking 50 feet to the AUGUSTUS tower elevators i walk about 300yds to the PALACE tower elevators which are in no-mans land it seems. Im located on the 10th floor. I open the door, and to my displeasure im greeted by 1 KING bed (i had booked 2 Queens). Now if i wasnt staying with my 55yr old mother, i wouldnt have been to pissed. But being that im not 11yrs old anymore, sleeping with your mother is alittle weird in my book. So i call to the front desk and ask for someone to talk to.. They transfer me to call HOUSEKEEPING. I talked to someone and they inform me that a ROLL-AWAY bed will be an extra $30 dollars! So i agree, and within 30mins a man knocked on the door with the bed. About 730-8pm we arrive back at CP from having a wonderful Thanksgiving dinner at "The Tillerman" steakhouse on flamingo rd, only to be told that since we arent "checking in" that we would have to self park. We explained that we were guests of the hotel and that we had valet'd earlier without problem. After getting serious additude from the valet kid (string bean white kid) we talked to a "manager" that told string bean to park our car. So at CHECK-OUT the next morning i explained my situation to the clerk, and she managed to adjust the $30 roll-away charge OFF my room's bill. Ive had better customer serive DOWNTOWN for 1/3 the price. Will not return. Btw, our room did overlook the 7 pools that no one seemed to be at.

Definitely the best holiday I have ever been on and probably the most fun week I have ever had.	Coming from the UK to Las Vegas In a small group.Earlier this year we decided that for my dads 60th we would all go on a trip to Las Vegas. This trip was to spend quality family time and to have a whole lot of fun. We looked up and down the strip, checked websites, read blogs and there were pros and cons to every hotel. Some are newer, some have particular features, but in terms of location, amenities and what the hotels have to offer for entertainment and dining, we selected Caesars Palace. Having spent some time trying to organise the trip from the UK, making transatlantic phone calls and surfing a host of websites trying to book, I was introduced to Harrahs Total Experiences programme where we had a dedicated member of staff to assist in organising our trip. Prior to departure we worked jointly to plan an itinerary, and when we arrived everything was sorted and reserved- we were put in a good room, no cheeky $20 at the desk!As a group of four we all had different plans in what we wanted to do during the day. Timothy played poker tournaments, Orry and Robin took advantage of the golf courses and the perfect sunshine and being centrally located, I could wonder about, do some shopping and admire the other hotels the strip.We could enjoy ourselves safe in the knowledge that tickets were booked for the best seats, reservations were made in the best restaurants and no time was wasted, as we skipped every queue to sit in the best VIP areas of nightclubs and not just in the Harrah's properties.We were treated like royalty, and I am sure people were asking, who are these guys with the best seats in the house? but I was not totally surprised, as we look a bit like a boy band as you can see in the photos!There were so many highlights in the 6 days, but it would be remiss not to mention a couple of special things. The Qua Spa at Caesars is among the best in the world. I was so relaxed, I didnt want to leave. Planned to go once, went 3 times and worth every penny. Wish I discovered it earlier in the trip. The cooking at Bradley Ogden was great. Some restaurants have more Michelin Stars, but this is proper cooking for proper people, with the best service in Vegas. We went to Robuchon at MGM, and although French Cuisine is great, you can get it in London (or indeed France!)  It was a dream come true for my dad to meet Bette Midler and get his photo taken with her. Her show was a medley of songs, jokes, stories and dancing and only possible in Vegas. Three weeks later and the photo with Bette has replaced my mothers picture on his office desk! I have a soft spot for old Las Vegas and the neon flashin and one arm bandits crashin, so taking a wonder down Fremont Street ignited a feeling of nostalgia of a bygone era. Would recommend it to all travellers! On previous visits to Las Vegas, we just couldnt get into Pure and other nightclubs being a group of guys. As we booked with Total Experiences, Harrah's arranged for us to be VIPs, dancing and singing with Shaggy on stage, cool! Having dinner at Paris in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower and with the backdrop of the Bellagio Fountains was a perfect way to spend our last night.So thats it. As Robin said, Definitely the best holiday I have ever been on and probably the most fun week I have ever had.i would recommend the hotel, but moreover recommend booking through the Total Experiences programme if you are a group planning a trip, or a stag or a golf break, as they just sorted access and everything we needed on the trip for us, including nightclubs, golf etc. Having organised stag trips from London to Vegas before, I know what a chore it is.They have a website- google, harrah's total experiences or if you are in the UK send me a message and i'll pass on details to Dani who organised our trip (probably not best to pass on personal details on an open forum!!!)OL

Can't wait to go back!	The best 5 days holiday I've ever had. Service second to none - we English think we know what service is but we have no idea. These guys are the ultimate professionals from the bellhop to the top managers. As with some other reviewers, we were, at first, put into a very inferior room in the forum tower but I called reception and 5 minutes later we were in the palace tower in the room of our dreams! Don't know why they keep trying this trick - can anyone hazard a guess? We enjoyed every single exciting second of our visit and can't wait to go back.

Nov 21 2009 	First and Last time staying at Caesars	My husband and I go to Vegas every fall. We had never stayed at Caesars, so we figured we would give it a try. We were in the Palace Tower. The room was clean and very nice, but the only view we had was of another building. We didn't have a room service menu in the room, so I called down and they said they would send one right up. Well, we never did get our menu! The ice machine on our floor and also on 2 other floors would not work and we called the front desk twice about this before it was fixed. The coke machine also didn't work on 3 different floors that we tried and they took our money. The buffett is way overpriced for what they offer. The breakfast buffett was good, but not worth the price. Expect to put on your walking shoes because it takes forever to get anywhere in the hotel, especially from your room to the casino. This was also one of the smokier casinos that I have been in. We smelled like walking ashtrays the whole time we were there and we do not smoke. The only good thing I have to say about Caesars is that we did win some money there! But we will not be back!

Nov 20 2009 	Choose your room carefully!	I traveled to Vegas with my mother, who is has Diamond status with the Harrah's hotels.At Caesar's Palace, this gives you access to your own registration desk & other niceties, but we learned that it doesn't guarantee a decent room.They put us in the Colossus Tower, and the room was a real shock! Our two "queen" beds were really doubles, and the room was so small that there was ~6" of space between the ratty couch by the window and the closest bed.But the beds themselves were just perplexing! One was okay, on par with what you'd expect to find in a decent Sheraton or Marriott - lots of padding between the mattress & sheet, nice bedding, 3-4 pillows. The other bed, though, looked like a Motel 6 refugee: a thin sheet over a poor-quality mattress, and two skimpy pillows.So I tried to call the front desk, but the line just rang and rang. Tried the hotel operator, who stayed on the line until she could connect me to someone at one of the front desks. We were immediately moved to a room in the Augustus Tower, which was more in line with what we were expecting.The bellhop sent to transfer our luggage said he didn't know why they still rented out rooms in the Colossus & Roman Towers (the oldest parts of the hotel). Once we saw our new room, I totally agree with him. It was like moving from a Comfort Inn to an upscale boutique hotel! Our new room was significantly larger, and included a seating area, a dining table with 4 chairs, two Actual Queen Beds with plenty of fluff & pillows, mini-bar, flat-panel tv, and a luxurious bathroom: dual sinks, separate toilet room, jacuzzi tub, and glass-enclosed shower.Even the elevator lobbies and the hallway carpeting were a BIG step up in quality and appearance. If you visit the hotel's website, they don't even mention the Colossus or Roman Towers. The 360-view of a room in the Palace Tower is very similar to what we had in the nearby Augustus Tower. It really was as if we'd checked into 2 completely different hotels!Also, the spa is located in the Augustus Tower, and is well worth a trip. We both signed up for massages that were just wonderful, and we gave ourselves plenty of time to enjoy the "Roman Baths," Saunas, etc., before & after. Note: if you need a robe larger than ~2X, consider bringing your own. While we were checking in, another guest discovered that they didn't have enough larger-size robes to meet demand. It was a bit awkward for everyone!Caution: the price they charged us was a bit higher (~$30 each) than what we were quoted on the phone for our massages. When we said something, the clerk just shrugged his shoulders & kept processing our payment. We didn't push, but I urge you to watch for that, in case it's a common practice.Long story short: location, location, location. Avoid the Colossus & Roman Towers like the plague unless/until they have been completely overhauled & renovated! Maybe they should just raze the buildings & start over.

Nov 19 2009 	Part of the Las Vegas experience	A stay at Caesar's Palace should be an essential part of a visit to Las Vegas but, be warned, compared to most of the other casinos, it is very expensive. We got a very good deal which included tickets to Bette Midler plus a nights stay for a reasonable price but we tried to book an extra night and found a fairly standard room to be $200 with no chance of a discount. In the end we booked across the road (literally) at Hurrahs and got a superior room for a quarter of the price!That said, the one night we had was a great little bit of luxury which added to the whole experience of being in Las Vegas. It was good to see the (wonderful) show and then just go up in the lift to bed. The room had all we could ask for and more with a great view and so was worth paying a bit over the odds just for one night. I think Caesar's Palace play too much on their name to keep prices artificially high, so be aware you can get much better deals in equally good accomodation elsewhere.

Nov 18 2009 	One of the best hotels I've stayed in	One of the nicest hotels on the Las Vegas strip, within walking distance to all the main attractions like the Pirate Show at Treasure Island, The Bellagio Fountains, Paris and the Miracle Mile shops.Caesars Palace is huge, you need a day in your itinerary just to walk around the hotel and the in hotel "forum shops".We arrived and were presented with an option to upgrade our room for an extra $140 USD for our 3 night stay, which we did. The upgrade took us into one of the towers overlooking the Bellagio fountains. We had a double shower, jacuzzi, huge TV, couch and table.I recommend you talk to the person who checks you in and see what upgrades are available at the time of check in.Overall this hotel is great, the food in the hotel is devine and the shopping is fantastic. You will lose yourself in a world of luxury.. without paying too much money for it! You will feel like a celebrity!

Nov 17 2009 	Pay for the upgraded rooms if you stay - classic rooms not worth it	I thought I would splurge for a nicer hotel for my 25th birthday, instead of TI, MGM, definitely am not a fan of luxor. I thought Caesars would be nice, classy, and the rooms would be more impressive than what we have usually gotten year after year. Not the case. We were in a classic room not in a newer upgraded tower. If you stay here make sure to get a new tower room or suite, otherwise the rooms at TI and MGM are 10 times better. The bathroom was horrible, so small, little closet space, beds and linens horrible quality. Luckily the shopping and entertainment are all there so it does have a good location. Overall it was an ok stay, but I will not stay there again.

Nov 16 2009 	First time at Ceasars - and last	Went to Ceasars for a convention and booked 2 extra days to enjoy Vegas. When we checked in we were told that we were booked into their smallest room and we "may not find it adequate". We were offered an upgrade to a nicer room for an additional $40 per night which we declined. I asked about an in-room coffee maker and was told "No, but we have 24 hour room service available" (a 3-cup carafe of coffee was $12.00). I asked about the fitness facility and was told "Yes, we have a world-class fitness facility available to guests for $25 each per day or a 3 day pass is available for $50 each". I asked about the pool and was told that the pool complex was closed (mid-November but 80 degrees and sunny) but there was a pool available to hotel guests for $10 each M-F or $20 each SS. I asked about wi-fi access and was told it too was available for $10 additional per day. Our room was in the Roman tower. It was dated with peeling wallpaper, and there were peanut shells on the floor which I was able to find with my bare feet. The room had a strange layout with no door on the bathroom. It had a nice view of the roof of the adjoining building. All this for the reduced rate of $250 per night (regularly $400). Needless to say, I let my employer pay for the two days there to attend the conference and then switched my remaining two days to a neighboring hotel on the strip for half the price and enjoyed a nice room with all the amenites that cost extra at Cesars for free, including a great pool. Cesars enjoys a great reputation as one of the premier places to stay on the Las Vegas Strip. From my experience, this reputation is not well deserved and a stay at another property is recommended. Thanks for reading and enjoy your stay in Las Vegas!
Nov 16 2009 	Everything in one Place	A traditional hotel keeping with pride its traditional quality and elegance. Everything is here, good restaurants, famous stores, good shows, excellent bars

Nov 11 2009 	First time at Caesars	We got there a little early and was not able to check in yet, so stored bags with them and went off to have some fun. Around 1:00 went back to see if we could check in and was able to. We were comped a room in the Augustus tower. Very nice room, large and clean. Right away, we tried to store my purse in the safe and it was not working, so we called and someone came up to fix it. The tech said it was working and left. Again, when we tried to lock up my purse it was doing the same thing, so I just decided I would keep my purse with me. The beds were a little uncomfortable (felt like either really cheap mattresses or mattresses that needed to be replaced) The bed pillows were worn out too. The overhead light in the bathroom did not work and the first night, the jacuzzi tub would not work (but it did the second night-so it may have been something I was doing wrong to try to get it on). One evening we tried to rent a movie and had trouble getting that to start, so called the desk twice and they said they would reset something and they did and the movie did start after that. These are my only complaints about the room. Other than that, we were comfortable in the room, it was quiet, never heard any noise. Ordered room service for breakfast both mornings, took 45 minutes to an hour to arrive, but they told us that when he placed the order. It was a little on the high side, but was worth the convenience. Food was good and plentiful. Ate in the Augustus Cafe for dinner one evening, food was good. We also ate at the food court for lunch one afternoon. It was good there also. Everyone on this site has been complaining about the prices of food, but my opinion is when you stay at a higher end hotel, you really need to expect the food will cost a little more. By the time we left, we had enough comp points to cover the extra costs we incurred. Although I enjoyed the hotel, I do not know if I would stay there again. I was really disappointed with the casino, so many older machines that are literally worn out. We like to play bar poker and was not comfortable at any of the bars. We played bar poker at the Venetian as well as Bellagio, had much more fun there, the bars were quieter and not as brightly lit up. We like to choose a hotel that we can come back to in the evening and spend a few hours gambling there and then only have to walk a short way to our room. Nov 10 2009 	It is Vegas but when it comes to customer service don't take your chances.	I recently stayed at Caesars Palace and was quite disappointed in my choice. I had believed that this hotel could be mentioned with the better names in the area, but did not find it to meet my expectations.I had decided to give the hotel a shot when I saw a promotion that was being run over Halloween weekend on Twitter. It sounded like it would be a fun time and what put me over the top was when I saw that the first people to sign up for the promotion would have their room upgraded.I was worried about my upgrade so I sent a tweet to make sure this upgrade was still available (was I in that first X number of people to sign up). They said yes. I still didn't trust it, so to confirm I contacted the hotel through their website as well.When I went to check-in the clerk saw there was a note that I had asked about this upgrade...however, they told me this room was no longer available. I was disappointed and hoping they would care enough to make this up to me in some way. They didn't.I was thinking about staying an additional night beyond what I had reserved, so I asked them if they could do anything for me in this area (the list price for the room for this extra night which was a Sunday was $250- in comparison I knew I could get a room at the Bellagio for that night at $118, so I figured there might be some room to work). No luck.I headed up to my room. It looked ok- nothing special- not terrible, but not worth the price I paid. I checked out the bed- not that comfortable. Later I went to take a shower- handle is broken so it doesn't stay at the hot water side of things. Ok, so I'm stuck with a bad room- maybe it could at least be clean? Housekeeping comes by- my friend is in the bathroom, can you come back in 10 minutes? Ok. We leave. Back in 6 hours...still dirty.So we've stayed two nights, want a third, but there's no deal so we're off to the Bellagio. Time to check out. The clerk asks how the stay was, but obviously doesn't care. I started to say 'actually it wasn't very good...'- but he wasn't really interested. I continued to explain what had happened with the room at check-in...yeah, whatever, you have a $3 balance- shall I put that on your credit card?So that last part kinda sums it up for me. Will everything go right on every stay? No. But what's the attitude when it doesn't? We couldn't wait to get out of there and so we left the hotel at 8am on Sunday and went to the Bellagio. We knew it was very early but asked if we could check in. The clerk said 'I don't think we can do that for someone who is only staying one night'...before laughing and finding us a room. We may have been lucky that there was something available, but from the friendly service I knew they would do their best to take care of us. It was like the opposite of being in Caesars.

Nov 2 2009 	Great conference trip	Have decided to write reviews for all the places I've stayed in Vegas, but be warned that my stay here was over a year ago, so things may have changed.I was apprehensive about coming here because I've heard things about how campy and outdated they are. I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. Yes, there's an awful fountain of naked muses in the lobby right when you enter, and there are similarly bad imitations of Classical sculpture everywhere in the hotel, but it's Vegas, so that's to be expected! I was there for a conference and my employer had already pre booked everything. The check in staff were very pleasant and offered a tempting upgrade to a better room for a mere $30 a day. I waffled, then agreed to the offer. When I got to my room, I was stunned--what a great bargain! It wasn't the largest room in the world, but it was around 500 sq. ft, VERY ample space. The decor did not make my eyes hurt. The bathroom was huge and had a TV as well as a jacuzzi tub. And it only came for $30 more! I slept very well--it was quiet and the air smelled clear (rare in Vegas).The conference center was also a pleasant surprise. Very well appointed and large. It was hard to get to from my rooms though. And it was so big I got lost. The casino was average--seemed a bit empty, but the economy had just tanked when I was there (October 2008). The one restaurant we went to, Rao's was good but pricey. I think they were trying to capitalize on their reputation as one of the hardest restaurants to book in New York. I'm still very much an MGM Grand fan when it comes to restaurants, though. Maybe I am limited, but it just seems easier and more dependable, since they've managed to amass just about every noteworthy chef on the face of the earth over there.My colleagues was a bit annoyed with the catering staff at this hotel for our business luncheon, and I must say that they were pretty rude to her regarding her gluten allergy. But that aside, I had a very nice experience here, certainly better than the Venetian, which is supposedly a better hotel.

Oct 18 2009 	best holiday ever	We stayed in caesers with another couple for 10 nights,a bit pricey but no other complaints,cheesecake factory is the best place to eat,good food and big portions reasonable price,perfectly placed on the strip.excellent experience will definately return.

Oct 17 2009 	Got money to burn and don't plan to win any- stay here	Husband and I went for 21st wedding anniv. Since this was my 1st time in vegas we thought we would splurge on the room and got the suite with a jumbo spa tub. That was very nice, it fills up very quickly. The shower head in the stand up glass door shower (very nice too) was so powerfull that it was like piercing needles so you had to have it barely on or else your scalp would be sore. The mini bar was of course way over prices and they are movment sensitive (including the items on top) so dont pick them up to look at. You can request a mini fridge from housekeeping (no cost) and keep drinks and your own liquors in that (recommended!) buy your sodas, snacks from the walgreens or CVS stores- much cheaper!!! Liquor in the malls at the ABC stores are also much cheaper. The machines don't pay off nearly as much as the Freemont street ones. The tables are higher bets than the smaller casino's. If you want to eat cheaper try Burker king inside Osheas for breakfast or walk a little further to Denny's. Inside bill's casino (across the street) is a nice resturant to get a large breakfast for under $10 each. Look out for breakfast deals in the mall dining places ($3.95-$10) while you are walking around and make note of those. Lunch is another thing we would usually not eat much for lunch since we were so full from breakfast. The pool areas looked nice- but we didn't go in them. While gambling on slots I hardly ever saw a cocktail waitress and even though I tipped her I wouldn't see her again. The drinks are also VERY weak- hince buy your own liquor and drink that while getting ready to go out! If I ever return to vegas I will stay at a cheaper casino and use the money for shows and better food choices for dinners, and gambling.

Oct 16 2009 	Great stay but extremely expensive!!	Stay at Caeser's from September 28th -Oct 3rd. When we arrived at 7:30 Pm I was told that our room was not ready yet. We then decided to go to the Diamond lounge and get a drink and something to eat because we were starving with the long flight from Phila. After going back to check on our room they said it would be another 1/2 hour, so we went to look around the hotel. The hotel is huge and has allot to see. we wanted to get aquainted with our surroundings since we heard is was difficult to navigate. In reading past reviews we were a liitle bit nervous with our room. We finally got our key's and went up to our room to be very happy. We were in the Augustus tower room 3370. It was right near the elevator and had a wonderful view of the Bellagio fountains outside our window, The rooms are like mimi suites. very large, has a couch and a few chairs, and the bathroom was awsome. Had a juccuzi tub, shower and TV in the bathroom so when you are taking a bath you can watch TV. rooms were very clean. As for the prices of food, come on give me a break!! I am by no means a cheap person, but $17.00 for a cheeseburger at the Cafe is crazy. Needless to say we ate elsewhere.As for the pool the way they designed the two newer towers is rediculous. You don't get any sun at all at the pool until 12:30 Pm. I sat at the pool for over 3 hours waitiing, and waiting, and waiting. They don't have enough chairs either. If you get down there in the afternoon to go to the pool, good luck trying to find a lounge chair. and oh by the way the drink prices are crazy too. $14.00 for a small drink and $22.00 for a large. That's why I brought a few beers in a small bag with ice to the pool. The sports book is huge and had allot of fun there. If you play keno they give you free drink coupons which came in handy considering the prices of drinks. All in all it was a great place to stay, very clean and comfortable.We were celebrating our anniversary and had a great time. Vegas will wear you out so bring good walking shoes and be ready to party!!!

Oct 15 2009 	Luxe suite makes stay superb	We were booked into a luxe suite w/ foyer, powder room, wet bar, living room, dining room, large bedroom, and large bathroom. Oct 14 2009 	Greatjust don't gamble here!	Spent four days at Caesar's with husband and another couple. I knew not to take my "pretty" shoes,but rather the walking shoes-good thing,too! From our room in the Palace Tower to the Flamingo,across the street was about a mile hike. Our room was large,lovely and comfortable. Beware the weight-sensitive mini-bar and amenties on top of the bar they want you to buy. $8 m&m's,seriously! With this type of luxury place you don't get a coffee pot,micro or fridge (that's dedicated to the mini-bar). My dear hubby hiked down to Payard's each morning and got me a $6 cup of coffee. Everyone was friendly except for the dealers who seemed not to like their jobs. Hubby plays craps and there was never anything but $25 tables. I never saw them busy or noticed anybody winning at anything,actually. We went across the street to the Flamingo to gamble where it was much more exciting with $5 and $10 tables. The craps crew at the F were surprized when we told them about the (mostly empty) $25 tables at Caesar's! They are both owned by Harrahs,I understand. We also went downtown to gamble and hubby won big at his favorite-Binion's. We had brunch at Bobby Flay's Mesa Grill (at Caesar's) and it was good-not as good as last time's meal at Wolfgang Puck's Bistro,tho'(at the MGM). All food we encountered at C's was very expensive. We were seated at Beijing Noodle #9 for dinner and after about 10 minutes with no service at all got up and left-they never even noticed. At the Seafood restaurant we were warmly welcomed and had great service and good food,tho' it is more Asian than seafood. Another meal was at a diner type place at the Flamingo-we were ready for a burger and it was good. We had dinner at Caesar's Augustus Cafe one night. As far as I know,it is the only 24-hr place to eat at C's. It was not very good with fair to poor service.Notes: It is very dry in Vegas,I couldn't moisturize enough,or get enough to drink. A 16 oz. (I think) soft drink at the shop in the lobby is $3.95. I tried to buy soda out of the machines on 2 floors-neither worked. Could they be trying to force you to buy those $6 drinks from the mini-bar?We rented a car because we went to Hoover Dam one day. Driving on the Strip is horrible-take a taxi or limo if you can. Oct 13 2009 	Surreal experience	It took me a long time to understand this whole 'Vegas Experience' , but it was certainly not what I expected. I booked Ceasars simply because of the name and the history. I expected high rollers, tuxedo's, show's starring Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin, that sense of a real piece of American history, that I as a European had not experienced before. At first I was bitterly disapointed in Vegas, there was no glamour, this really is a Kitsch city, and caesars the most kitsch hotel I have ever stayed in. The mental picture of glamour was instantly replaced by poor Mexican's handing out leaflets advertising porn and adult services, the tuxedo's relaced by baseball caps and shorts, The million dollar gambling tables replaced by 1000's of 25 cent slot machines. The beutiful people replaced by average americans with their large cups full of quarters. Then I got it, Las Vegas is not meant to be glamour, it is meant to be kitsch, infact it is meant to be the absolute pinnicle of kitsch, and you know what Caesars delivers it perfectly. Caesars and Vegas delivers a completely different experience to anywhere else in the world, complete with talking statues. You can see why this place is so popular with ordinary people, stag and hen parties, and the bemused foreigner, it provides a totally different experience based on excess, and fantasy.The rooms were fine, quite ordinary compared wit the rest of the hotel, and the service completely corporate and delivered to perfection. With the strength of the Euro against the Dollar, I found it to be reasonably priced, and we ate well in the various restaurants.Was it all for me? well no, and I have no intention of ever going back to this city. If you want this whole 'Vegas Experience' then I would actually recommend Caesars, it delivers it perfectly.

Oct 8 2009 	Classy hotel with wonderful theming but incredibly expensive	I stayed in an Augustus Tower room back during my first (and until this November, only) trip to Vegas for a wedding. The rooms were ungodly expensive, even pricey after dividing the price by 3 since I shared a room with two friends. Still, I must say the rooms were incredibly impressive and worth every penny. Extremely spacious and elegantly decorated. The bathroom itself was nearly as big as my bedroom at home, and had an enormous jetted tub, walk in shower, vanity with two sinks and a separate closet for the toilet. It was one of the the best hotel rooms I've ever stayed in, though the mattresses could have been a little softer. That said, from what I saw of a regular base level room (which they call Classic), I can't imagine that it'd be worth staying in this hotel if you weren't splurging on one of the more expensive rooms. The base level rooms weren't much better than a room at any run of the mill chain hotel yet are rented at rates higher than much of the strip. Caesars has one of the greatest locations of any of the resorts on the strip. Right in the middle of everything so walking to other resorts isn't as arduous as it could be. And that's if you even decide to leave the resort. Caesars has some of the best shopping in the area, the Forum Shops is easily my favorite shopping center on the strip. Lots of great restaurants are here, the spa is absolutely fabulous (even just paying the $45 to use the facilities at Qua is worth it, though for that much you ought to just get a treatment as their staff is wonderful), the pools are gorgeous and their show rooms host plenty of big name entertainers. It'd be very easy to check in here for a long weekend and never find a reason to leave the property.All and all, I'd have to say this is an excellent resort, though probably out of the price range of many travelers (myself included) as there are plenty of hotels nearby that offer rooms that are just as nice (or in the case of base level rooms, much better) for less. If you do have the opportunity to stay here though, I'm sure you won't regret it.

Oct 6 2009 	going downhill	We`ve been to Caesars every year for the last twenty-odd years, so it pains me to write this but....It seems to me, that unless you`re part of a huge group, or willing to pay out for lots of extras, they`re not really interested anymore.For example, if you want to sit by the pool, there are plenty of sunbeds but they`re all behind the double beds and canopied beds that, of course, cost extra. Also, one afternoon, we went down for a swim at around 4.50 pm to be told that all the pools and the whole area was closing at 5pm for a private function.This has happened to us before and I urge you all to complain to the duty manager if it happens to you. We did and received 100 dollars to spend on food and drink as compensation, but it really isn`t good enough. Oct 4 2009 	Again - a wonderful time at Caesars	We were at Caesars from Sept.23 to 30th and stayed in the Palace Tower (room 2344)and had a wonderful time. The first night it was so overbooked that they had to put us in the Roman tower, which from all reviews had me worried. It was actually not a bad room at all - mind you it is smaller and a bit dated but the walls were thick enough that we heard no noise at all. The next day they moved us to the Palace Tower which we requested because it is so close to the swimming pools which makes it the best location for us. We had two bathrooms in our room and the room was large, overlooking the pool area. We had ample towels and no problems at all, other than the housecleaning staff was a bit slow and could be cleaning a bit better, but the bed sheets were clean, and towels where plenty. We asked and received a small fridge for our left overs from our meals, which the next day made great sandwiches for lunch. We also asked for an extra cot which arrived free of charge. Finally the pools are complete and the new cabanas and day beds add a nice look to all the pools. The water was clean and warm - I do agree that the beds are a bit too close to each other, but people do spread out. We ate twice at the Mesa Grill, and once at Bradley Ogden - both are excellent. We also enjoy the food around the pool. One night we went to the Hofbrauhaus for Octoberfest celebrations and had a really fun evening. The keg-meister that evening was Lance Burton and he was very friendly and approachable. The food there was good German down home cooking and their staff was very friendly and helpful with explaining all the dishes. Another evening we ate at the Rio, at their Indian restaurant, and the food was delicious. We left the ordering up to the waiter, and he did a great job of giving us a good cross selection of delectible dishes. If you like sea bass, they did this one dish that I thought was amazing! We went to see Penn & Teller and I don't know if it was an off evening - but I didn't think they were all that good - Penn talked too much and talked very quickly and it was hard to understand him - I could have used less talking and more magic.In the end, everyone at Caesar's was curteous, friendly and professional. We go twice a year and have never had anything but the best - no complaints.They will see me again in April.

Oct 4 2009 	Terrible Hotel Rooms and Customer Service	I stayed at Caesars Palace for three nights while attending a business conference. At first, I was assigned a room in the Centurion Tower. The room was clean, but very dated and the mattresses were VERY hard. I would have been better off sleeping on the floor! The room view was terrible and looked straight into the a/c units. This caused it to be very loud at night. I could not sleep at all so very late that night I got dressed and went to the reservation area to see if I could be moved to another room. The employee stated that they did not have any rooms other than suites available. First off, they were incredibly rude and obviously hated their jobs. Second, she said they could upgrade me to a suite for $200 more per night. At this point, I was traveling alone so there was obviously no need for a suite. I just wanted a quiet room with a comfortable bed. I then asked what was available the next night. I was able to upgrade my room for $50 more a night. The room I was upgraded to was nice and the bed was comfortable, but still not worth what they are charging for the room. In addition, I paid $14.99 for 24 hours of internet service that could only be used in my room. When I switched rooms, they tried to tell me that I would have to purchase the internet again. I was persistent and refused to pay for the service again when I still had 12 + hours I already paid for. They did adjust the bill for this issue, but were rather rude in the process. The amenities at this hotel are nice and the business conference area was very nice. Before the conference, my husband and I stayed at Treasure Island and had a very nice experience. In addition, the bill for three nights at Treasure Island was less than half the amount of the hotel bill for Caesars Palace. I hardly ever leave comments about hotels, but my experience at Caesars Palace was awful and I felt it needed to be shared so others do not have to go through a similar experience. The hotel's employees seem to forget that they are working in the hospitality industry. There are too many other options in Vegas and I will not return to Caesars Palace.

I had the chocolate and bacon waffle which stunned me into silence, a real must-try.The MGM - Free lion attraction, great for kids and big kids alike. KA the show, pretty expensive but mind blowing and had us gasping for breath at the stunts.The Stratasphere - The rides at the top are great, do them in the dark for best effect. We also had dinner at the 'Top of the World ' restaurant. Great views, good service but really pricey. $300 for 4 of us for just mains and a bottle of wine. Try it as a treat if you dont go on a helicopter.The Bellagio - The fountain goes off through the day, but come alive at night! They go off every 15 mins and are fabulous, another freebie! The dress code in here was a bit more upmarket and most girls were in dresses.One last top tip - the taxi from the airport to caesars cost us $30 on the way to the hotel and $11 on our trip back.... done over as usual for being a tourist. Ask for the direct route and say that you have been before so they dont con you.p.s. everyone wants a tip and some will ask you for one. Dont be a woss and pay a taxi driver if he doesnt do a good job, we had one who wouldn't accept our payment until we added a tip - tell them where to go, you wont see them again!All in all, we would go back tomorrow. Fantastic!!!

Sep 30 2009 	Disappointing	The reception process was a brutal and bruising experience. We were not given the room that had been reserved on our behalf by our UK tour operator. Sep 30 2009 	SHOCKED 	Booked for 7 nights the room we booked was totaly unexceptable, shower blocked then all this black junck coming up through the drains! no backs on the the draws so clothes just fell through to the next draw, the entrance door was not fitted well with a 2 inch gap at one end.We were then upgraded to a great room with extra cost incured by US.Upgrade was great untill we tried to sleep. Sep 28 2009 	Great hotel fantastic location pity about the service	If you're staying in Vegas then Caesar's is probably in one of the best locations, roughly in the middle of the strip. Sep 26 2009 	Great pool but hotel is old and it's obvious--not the best in vegas!	My boyfriend and I stayed at Caesar's Palace while in town for my cousin's wedding. We were very excited to stay here, especially since the movie "The Hangover" and had just come out. Needless to say, the movie makes the hotel look a hell of a lot nicer than it is. Don't get me wrong, the lobby is pristine, the pool is immaculate and the forum shops are of course amazing. We spent almost every night dining at some of the fantastic restaurants in the forum shops, like Il Mulino, Boa Steakhouse, Sushi Roku and Spago. If not for the forum shops we would have been very disappointed.Our room was old and not kept well. It was a standard suite, and had a great view of the pool, but the bed was uncomfortable and had an old pink comforter like a motel. The bathroom was all marble and beautiful, except for one major problem---there was no door!!! Thankfully my boyfriend and I have been together long enough for this not to be a deal-breaker, but we were still uncomfortable with using the facilities with the other person in the same room and no door. Also, one afternoon water started pouring out of the ceiling vent above our toilet. We called down immediately and maintainence told us that it was from the room upstairs' tub overflowing. Obviously there was nothing they could have done to prevent this, but it still left a bad taste in our mouths. The spa there was amazing. It had several roman baths and jacuzzi's, and even had an arctic room which is set at 55 degrees and has fake snow! It was incredibly beautiful and relaxing.We were expecting a lot more from Caesar's Palace and unfortunately our expectations weren't met. The first night we arrived there was a group of housekeeping carts being stored on our floor right by our room. We called down to let them know and they said they would move them. The same thing happened the second night, only the carts were never moved. This happened every night of our 5 night stay and we complained several times. The casino was old and dreary. All of the dealers looked as if they had one foot in the grave (or wished they did) and the whole set up was very cheesy. The forum shops casino, however, was beautiful. The regular caesar's casino had very low ceilings and not a lot of things to do.The location of Caesar's was great--it's right in the middle of everything. But for the location, the Bellagio right next door was ten times as nice. My dad and his girlfriend were staying there and we wanted to be there all the time. The casino was beautiful and huge, the restaurants were yummy and trendy and it even had a better nightlife than Caesar's.We also visited the famous club Pure at Caesar's but it was not much to look at. It was extremely crowded and filled with really pretentious people. We are from Boca Raton, FL which is arguably one of the snobbiest places in the country, so we are definitely familiar with this crowd, but still had a hard time stomaching the one in Pure. Wouldn't recommend it but it was great for the awesome $90/night rate that we got. If you want luxury, stay at the Bellagio, Wynn, or even the new Palazzo.

Sep 26 2009 	Great hotel centrally located on strip	Checkin went very good, short line and we were given a great room. The windows are from ground to ceiling so we had a great view over the strip and the rest of the city, especially at night.Selfparking was easy, the parking garage is large and you can park your car near the elevator which leads you into the casino. Also the shops (Forum Shops) are great to see but a little bit expensive. The Apple store was also there.We only had breakfast once in the hotel, there are several counters where you can buy different kind of foods, and also over here the personel is very helpful.The location is perfect, when you walk out of the hotel, you are in no time in The Venetian, Paris, Bellasio, Treasure Island etcetera. If you have an hotel which is further down the strip it is a long walk to get to the central strip. So we walked around the casino's and saw all the fabulous things in the hotels (aquarium, canalboats, lions, rollercoasters).The swimming pool is very luxureus, it has multiple pools includinf one in which you can play poker! Sep 23 2009 	excellent visit to c elebrate 47th wedding anniversary	We stayed at Caesar's from 9/7-9/12/09 to celebrate our 47th wedding anniversary- We are diamond players therefore was given a room in the Argustus Forum on the 37th floor overlooking the fountains at the Bellagio- it was really beautiful at night to be able to overlook the strip and also see the fountains-We ate lunch 0b 9/11, around 2:45 at the Bellagion buffet and found the food delicious- decor a little dreary but the food was excellent- especially the cream spinach- everything was fresh, hot was hot, cold was cold, and plentiful.This was my 5th trip to Las Vegas but this was one of the most memorable.

Sep 18 2009	Classic Vegas everyone should experience at least once	Mixed views of this hotel. Overall I would recommend, Impeccable rooms, great location on the strip. Sep 18 2009 	Caesars Palace is Vegas at its best	I've been staying at Caesars Palace at least twice a year for the last 25 years and it continues to be one of the best hotels on the strip. Sep 15 2009 	Unexpected and wonderful!	Found on Hotwire for $99/night and decided to surprise my mom with a stay here.
