After reading reviews here I was worried that due to our booking method we would be relegated to one of the older towers and a room in disrepair. At check-in, I slipped $20 between my ID and credit card and asked if any rooms in the Augstus tower were available. We ended up on the 7th floor facing the Bellagio fountains, the room was wonderful with two queen beds, sitting area with a few small chairs, couch and coffee table, and a small dining table as well. Bathroom was spacious, separate shower and DEEP jacuzzi tub were both in good working order. She was shocked and delighted with the surprise switch in accommodations, and overall we couldn't have been happier with the room. Breakfast buffet was pretty good, would recommend heading over to Mirage for the Cravings buffet instead, its about the same price with much more variety and I think higher quality overall. Did not spend too much time on the gaming floor as I go to Vegas mostly to sightsee and go to shows. Hotel valet was quick and courteous and only once was it full during the Cher concert. Not sure if this would be the case during the peak summer months, but you wouldn't catch me dead in Vegas in the 100+ heat anyway! All and all, this was a great stay for a mother-daughter weekend and I would not hesitate to stay again. While not the newest or classiest hotel on the strip, Caesars is a place where you don't have to spend a ton to be treated like a first class visitor, and of course the location can't be beat for the Vegas sightseer or first time visitor!

Sep 15 2009 	Right in the middle of Vegas action	Spent 2 nights here at the end of a trip around California. Caesars is right at the heart of the strip so it was easy to see the main sites and the pool was pretty fun with ridiculous levels of roman decoration - caesar is on a podium in the centre of the pool pointing towards the buffet...there is also swim up poker and back jack so you dont need to head to the immense in door gambling hall if you dont want too. Food and drink prices in Caesars were massive however if you arent a big gambler with a poor glass of white wine costing $9 so worth heading to some of the other casinos for drinks if you arent planning to spend loads on the tables

Sep 14 2009 	In the Middle of Everything	We come to Vegas a few times a year and this was our first stay at Caesar's Palace. We had gambled enough back in March when we stayed at Paris, Las Vegas (both are member's of Harrah's Total Rewards) that we were able to stay for free. So the value of what we got for only paying about $36 in taxes for 3 nights was pretty high. We were given a room in the Palace Tower on the 23rd floor that overlooked the pools. A good view and the room was very nice with a large bathroom.The best thing about Caesar's Palace is that it is in a great location, right in the middle of the strip. If you want to venture out it's a great starting point. But also, at the same time, if you don't want to leave there is more than enough right there to keep you plenty busy. We like the casino and the large sports book at Caesar's. We're in our 30's and Caesar's has done a great job of infusing youth with their clubs with the older generation that has been coming back since the 1970's. It was packed from when we got there on Thursday to when we left on Sunday night.The pool area is very nice and the pools were heated even though it was over 100 degrees outside, which we liked. We were able to stay cool by the pool since half of the pool area spends most of the day in the shade, which has its pluses and minuses. It was impossible for 4 of us to find spots in the sun but we were able to stay cooler in the shade and hand out in the sunny side of a few of the pools. We bought a few rounds of beers at the store right by the entrance of the pool area instead of from the waitresses to save some money and make sure we didn't have to wait too long for the next round of drinks.Overall, I would say that Caesar's is right on par with some of the nicer Vegas hotels we stayed at but still a small step below a 5 star, maybe a 4.5 or a 4.75. We will definitely come back. It's a great place.

Sep 14 2009 	Nice hotel excellent location	We stayed at Caesars Palace for five nights in September 2009, the hotel is incredibly centrally located on the Strip and is in an excellent position to walk to most of the main hotels on the Strip. Sep 12 2009 	Consistently Delivers A Superb Experience	I've come to Las Vegas 2-3 times a year for the last 25 years and have stayed at several hotel-casinos including several of what many consider upscale ones. Sep 12 2009 	Beautiful Place to Stay but the slots are tight!!	My husband and I were there Sept. 5-9, 2009. We have stayed here many times over the last 8 years. Our room in the Augustus Tower was very nice. The slots were very tight, just like they were when we went in April, 2009. The $1 Wheel of Fortunue slots at Caesars do occasionally hit the $1,000. We also tried Harrah's and Flamingo and can honestly say we didn't see anyone winning large jackpots. In fact we only saw 2 people in 4 days win hand/cash pays. Also, Slots of Fun has upgraded their slots, this was one of the few places left that actually still used coins - now it's paper just like the rest. It was kind of sad to see all of the old machines gone. The slot tournament at Caesars was very nice (over 1,100 players). Also, Penazzi Oyster Bar at Harrah's has excellent food and the prices are reasonable! Good luck if you go, just plan on not bringing much money home.

Sep 11 2009 	Perfection	Me and BFF always wanted to stay at Caesars and are fans of Bellagio. Glad we tried it! Arrived at 8AM on a Sunday morning and they had a Fountain View room available in the Augustus Tower. The room was perfect for 2 women. 2 queen beds, large bath room with jetted tub and the view was wonderful. Plenty of room for both of us to get ready. Beds were very comfortable. Hallways clean and maid service was excellent. Plenty of towels and goodies everyday. The pool was still under a bit of construction, but very nice for traveling without children. Kids would not like this pool. Drinks were expensive but STRONG and worth it. Very tasty Mango Margarita's! QUA spa is the best in LV. The Roman tubs, Arctic Ice room and steam were heaven as was the spa treatment. We did not eat any meals at Caesars so i can not rate that. I would stay here again in a heartbeat!

Sep 11 2009 	LOVED IT!	We stayed for 3 nights starting from Sunday during Labour Day weekend. We were originally given a Classic Tower Room and we extremely disappointed. Sep 11 2009 	Fantastic	My husband and I went to Vegas in October. We stayed at Caesars and it was fantastic. Sep 10 2009 	great hotel for all !!	We had heard the bad reviews about this hotel but they could not have been further from the truth. Sep 10 2009 	Fantastic Location Great pool	I booked this hotel about 3 months in advance and got a fantastic deal it was preety much half price through Expedia.com. On checkin we signed up for a casino rewarder card which is free and gives you a $20 dinning voucher so that was good value.The hotels location is so good for it is close to the other hotels that hold attracts eg Bellargio fountain display right next door and the pirate show held at treasure island just down the road.The room was in the roman towers and really large with 2 double beds. The bathrooms and really large with a bath and a shower and plenty of room to put you items. Did I mention drinks are expensive.You can get a strip bus to the shopping out lets. I would recommend only going to the Premium outlet for it has the same stores as the basic one and also much better ones, also it is easy to get back to the strip from the premium outlet.The only downfall is that the view was not great and the service in the buffet area not great. But all in all a highly recommended hotel.

Sep 9 2009 	Rather Okay	We arrived after midnight and should have been heading for bed. We decided to go down to play slots "Just for a little while". We went fot breakfast across the street at Imperial Palace. Still not a very good buffet. Two bloody Mary's there.....Drunk again............. Back to bed and up at 4:30 to head to Excalibur for the Tournament of kings show(which was okay). We headed downtown that night and had a pretty good time. While visiting the pool at Caesars(which I figured would be one of the more enjoyable things to do there) I was pretty disappointed. I could hear this pounding base music from the bar close by which sort of over-rided the relaxing pool music we were supposed to be hearing. I just couldn't relax and ended up going across the street to get our show tickets for that day at tix for tonight.(Legends in concert 2for1 and George Wallace) Both shows were pretty good. When I got back to the pool my wife wasn't very happy because of the distracting sounds from over yonder. (Base from bar and construction). We headed out for a nice lunch. The room we had reserved was the Forum Tower Deluxe but when she found out we were Diamond Club members she automatically upgraded us to the Augustus Tower which is very close to the Diamond Lounge. I was really expecting something special because I had heard that the Forum tower rooms were quite good and the Augustus tower is a lot more expensive. My wife was very happy with the room and I have to admit I was pleased as well. I remember the shower havig multiple shower heads and there was a jucuzzi tub as well. Lots of stone and marble. Great TV. We could see the Bellagio Fountains (or at least the top of them) as our window was facing south. I just enjoyed looking outside to sort of get a feel for what was going on out there. We could see the busy Flamingo/Las Vegas Strip corner and all the people walking around. I don't want to stay at this place again as I prefer to come down the elevator and be able to walk right into a casino or go right out to the street without having a stroke. Next time it's back to the Flamingo for a little less luxury and a lot less wandering through seemingly endless walkways, entrances and rooms. Also for a tip. I'm pretty careful not to lose money on the slots, but at Caesars and Paris its almost impossible not to. Didn't eat at any of the restaurants. The Diamond club in Atlantic City has a full meal to offer and luxurious surroundings. The Diamond clubs at Vegas have chicken wings and chips and dip. Overall I still love Vegas and can't wait to go back next March!!

Sep 8 2009 	Enjoyed my stay at Caesars	Room - Augustus Tower 2 Queen bed corner room 3 nightsHaving been to Las Vegas four times it was about time I stayed at Caesars Palace. I Have stayed at all the major 5* hotels on the strip like Venetian, Wynn, MGM, ect. I booked the room directly from the hotels website with a special room rate code I found on the internet. upon checkin, which was about 11pm there was a short line. The clerk at the desk gave us a corner room which is located at the end of every corridor, the corner rooms are much bigger then a normal room and i would defiantly recommend asking for this room when you checkin. The rooms are nice and big with a huge bath tub. I would say rooms are just nice and they dont have the WOW factor like the rooms at the Wynn. I was happy with the rate I paid for the room, but had I paid normal Caesars rates i would of been a bit disappointed. The Casino is big and a bit hard to navigate at first as you find your self going round in circles. The slots in Caesars are probably the tightest i have played and youll find your $20 gone in about 2-3 mins.As for the food, make sure you try the serendipity3 restaurant which is located just outside Caesars, the food is amazing and the deserts are even better. make sure you ask to sit outside and enjoy your food while sitting in the middle of the vegas strip. As for the restaurants in the hotel, we tried the Augustus cafe for breakfast and was not very impressed. The pool area is also just OK and also a bit outdated, they are currently in the process of building a new pool which should be opening soon, even though their is construction pool side, you wont notice it. Make sure you take ID with you to the pool as you cant order anything on the room without it.All in all, I enjoyed my stay at Caesars and would recommend staying here if you get a good room rate. Also remember that this hotel is right in the centre of the strip which makes the location ideal.

Sep 8 2009 	Amazing Time In Vegas	7 students. 4 guys and 3 girls... stayed at Caesars Palace from a Sunday to a Thursday because of the cheap rates.Most amazing trip of our lives.I'm not someone for the bar scene and the clubs were soooo much fun!! Sep 6 2009 	Best hote of our trip	Have read a few of the reviews and am surprised at the negative comments... we were obviously very lucky as our room was fab and just what we wanted for a one-night stay. Check in was relatively quick, despite queues, and we had a friendly check-in clerk who upgraded us to Augustus Tower. Not sure why and we did'nt question it... but presumably a good move as we had a lovely, very clean, very comfortable room with lots of luxury extras. We did Las Vegas for our son - and spent our evening wandering the hotel and streets for the atmosphere. Ceasars made it acceptable for us "oldies" - however the pool was full of mostly "stag" and "hen" parties (lots of cocktails and beer on the go and lots of heavy flirting). We enjoyed the facilities, but thought the pool was a bit mucky because of plastic cups, fag ends etc especially after the odd gust of wind. The best margarhitas of the trip though!If you're going to book, then make sure you spend a little extra... however, think this is a general problem in Las Vegas as we went to visit Circus Circus (again for our son) and found that incredibly "tired".However we did have the most amazing "all you can eat" buffets in one of the restaurants - think it was Cafe Lago - which satisfied our requirements on the night. Definitely not a Michelin starred experience, but a great way to get good value and good food, with pretty good service too. Alcoholic drinks were expensive but the sodas were OK.

Sep 6 2009 	A great place to stay	This was my first time staying at Caesars Palace.I have usually stayed at other hotels.I have to say beginning with the check in the service was quick and helpfull.I had a free upgrade with the package i booked with Westjet vacations.The room i got was in the palace tower and a deluxe room.The room had a pool view.It was very clean.I was very happy with the room.Maid service was very good.The only downfall was the reception on tv wasn't great on all channels but who goes to Vegas to watch tv?The room had lots of room.The room had a double jacuzzi tub,double sinks,seperate shower.Is any place perfect of course not but i have to say i had no problems staying there friendly and helpful staff,clean rooms at a reasonable price.
Sep 6 2009 	Caesar's is there to make you stay fantastic!	Nicest hotel I have ever stayed in. Best service I have ever received. Received a GREAT rate.

Sep 5 2009 	Loved Caesars!	This was our fourth visit to Vegas, previously having stayed at Luxor, TI and The Mirage. We don't gamble much, just a few $ on the slotties, so we never get comps or anything, so I am commenting on the hotel as a tourist rather than on the casino etc.We stayed for 4 nights, having got the 4th night free through our booking with the UK travel company. The really pleasant guy on the check-in said he would upgrade us to the Palace tower, and our room was lovely. On the 15th floor, with a partial Strip view, very spacious, and a huge bathroom with a double Jacuzzi. It was bright and spotlessly clean. As usual, the mini-bar was extortionately priced, but this is the same the world over, and there was a large ice-bucket and plentiful ice available to chill your own wine that you've bought from the store for a few dollars. Coffee making facilities would have been nice, but that's my only very small niggle about the room.The lifts (elevators) were almost instantaneous despite being on floor 15, and all of the public areas were clean and well maintained. The concierge was very helpful when we wanted to book a show but there was a long queue as there was only one lady on the desk.We didn't eat in the hotel apart from by the pool one day, and although expensive, the portions were huge and very tasty; I had a mozzarella salad which was enormous and covered both my lunch and, as we English say, high tea ;-). Again, the drinks around the pool are way over-priced with two small tins of Corona beer coming in at around $15 plus tip!My only complaint about Caesars is the pool area. The pools themselves are lovely but if you don't get there early in the morning, 9.00am latest, you will struggle to get a sunbed. There is work going on at the moment which probably adds to the problem. Because of the high rise buildings around the pool, some beds are in the shade most of the day whilst others are in the sun with no shade at all; there were no parasols available or any tree cover, unless you paid the ridiculous sum of $250+ per day for a gazebo with sunbeds inside. Don't be fooled by the poster in the pool lobby which says these start from $25 per half-day. That probably means between the hours of 01.00am and 07.00am in January...Slight niggles aside, we loved Caesars. It is absolutely centre-strip which makes a real difference as you can do a hell of a lot of walking! And go to Jimmy Buffett's MargaritaVille directly across the road, not only for great Margaritas (of course) but they do a fabulous breakfast too!

Sep 4 2009 	Wonderful Room	Room - Augustus Tower Deluxe Room - stayed 2 nightsCheck in clerk was very nice and when we asked for 2 queen beds instead of 1 king, immediately changed our room  no problems at all. Sep 2 2009 	Caesars scores again.	My wife, son, and I visited Aug 21-24th. Had two rooms in the Palace Tower. Wife, a non-gambler, enjoyed the easy access to the pool and the spa. Sep 1 2009 	Diamond Player is NOTHING if you arent 7Stars at Caesars..poor service	I just returned from a trip to Vegas I average 4 trips a year....I normally stay at Paris/Rio/Ballys where I have never had a problem...I thought I would give Caesars another chance after a bad experience about 3 years ago.....well I made a POOR choice...the only thing I can say was my ROOM was nice....The main problem came when I tried to have a friend wire me some money...on his end Western Union was closed and being Sunday so were the banks...So he found a Moneygram service and sent me extra cash to GAMBLE with..After walking about 2.5 miles to get this I was told the Moneygram service at CVS only dispenses money orders...I thought this wouldnt be a problem to cash at the Casino based on my history with Harrahs....was I WRONG....not only would Caesars NOT CASH it they wouldnt even help me try to solve this problem...I spoke to a Casino Host and she just said "there's nothing we can do...we dont take money orders" WOW....didnt even spend 5 min trying to call anyone to help solve my problem.....so I was in a BAD situation...I went to Paris/Ballys to meet with my Host CHRISTINE MIKHAIL...not only did she spend time helping me she comped a LIMO to take me to cash my money order, along with the LIMO driver DAVE PEGULA....my crisis was solved and I WILL NEVER STAY/PLAY at caesars AGAIN......PARIS/BALLYS this is customer SERVICE.....to a Diamond Player...not 7stars as caesars only cares about.....even at check in/check out if your not 7stars FORGET ABOUT SERVICE.....at CAESARS

Aug 31 2009 	Not as expected...	We booked a package deal with Southwest Airlines and our room was in the Roman Tower. Boy, this was a plant for an upgrade for sure. Had a musty odor, window was directly in front of a concrete wall, lamps very dusty, carpets dirty and the mattress looked like it had a lump in the middle. When we called the front desk, we were quickly upgraded to a much better room in the Augustus Tower. The TV didn't work and after two calls, it was determined an electrician had to fix it, so we asked for another room and were granted one directly below (5 floors) our room, which was much better. I may stay there again if there was an option to pick the "tower" for an upgrade within a package deal... I don't like being given an undesirable room knowing you would have to upgrade. If this is a 4.5 star rated hotel, then all rooms should be as such or better.

Aug 30 2009 	Classic room- dont bother	Please let me warn you about the classic rooms. You really need to think wisely before booking this type of room. Really expected a lot more from Caesars. Location is fantastic but I recommend to anyone thinking of staying at Caesars. Either pay a little bit more and go to a deluxe room or prem room. Aug 30 2009 	Many better hotels in Vegas	We have just got back from a three-night stay at Caesar's Palace staying in one of the recently refurbished rooms in the Forum Tower. Having visited Vegas over 10 times we both agreed that this stay was probably the most disappointing visit we have had. Let's start with the room, refurbished and spacious yet the corridors were dirty and the cleaning trolley was permanently parked outside our room - nice! Aug 28 2009 	No Place Better	Completed another trip with a stay at Caesars. Can't say enough about the property. From the desk clerks to just about every employee, nothing but superb service. Aug 27 2009 	First Time In Vegas... Caesars Did NOT Disappoint	My husband and I visited Vegas for the first time August 19-21. My sister and brother-in-law joined us and we all had a great stay at Caesars. Many thanks to the reviews suggesting you inquire about the "complimentary upgrades" upon check-in. We reserved and paid for a Classic room and took our chances that we'd be upgraded. I folded up a $20 bill and held it in from of my id while checking in and asked if there were any complimentary upgrades available. I saw the lady glance at it and she said "Let me check." She was able to find us a suite in the Palace Tower and told me I really didn't have to tip her when I handed her the $20 (of course I did anyway.) She was very nice and professional about it. My brother-in-law planned on doing the same thing when he checked in, but forgot to use the word "complimentary." Instead, he was offered an upgrade to a 4000 sq. ft. suite (compared to our 2000 sq. ft. suite) in the new Augustus Tower. I think he paid around $160 total, which included 2 nights. They told him it was normally $200+ per night to upgrade, so it sounds like he got a good deal too. We reserved a smoking room and were very pleased with everything. The room was clean, very nicely decorated (see attached pics, I love blue & brown) and stocked with plenty of towels, etc. I did notice the next morning when I woke up that the room smelled like an ashtray, which was weird because it hadn't before. Then after the maid cleaned that day the smell was gone, so they must have a very powerful deoderizer. We were in the Palace Tower, Room 1742 and had a view of the pools, which open at 8:00. We went out right after 8:00 and had no problems with chairs. We only stayed 1 hour so I don't know exactly when it got crowded, but when I looked down around 3:00 or 4:00 I only saw 1 or 2 open chairs and they were not together. We ate breakfast at the buffet and it was great. Some people say there's not a large selection, but I'm not sure what you could want for breakfast that they didn't have... eggs, bacon, sausage, biscuits & gravy, muffins & other pastries, french toast, pancakes, cheese, fruit, etc. It was $18.95 if I remember correctly (definitely under $20) and worth it. We booked through Expedia and received a $50 food & beverage credit that could be used at any Caesars restaurant or bar, so our breakfast was "free." We tried the buffet at Terrible's for lunch and it was good enough. Pretty decent for what it costs - I think only $7 pp. We ate dinner at Joe's Seafood Prime Steak & Stone Crab in the Forum Shops mall and it was really good. Prices you can expect for a nicer Vegas restauraunt (anywhere from $30-$50 per plate plus extra for sides, salads, everything.) All in all, we had a great time in Vegas. Next time I'll want to stay at least one more night. We arrived late Wednesday and had to leave early Friday so we really only had 1 full day. The staff at Caesars were all very friendly and helpful in our experience. I would definitely stay here again if the price were right, but there are other places on the strip I'd want to try out too (Bellagio for one.) Make sure to catch at least one Bellagio fountain show. I think they run every fifteen minutes at night and they're really neat.P.S. I can't speak much for the gambling at Caesars b/c I only played the slots there, and did no good. We (all of us) had good luck on the Blackjack tables at O'Sheas though.

Aug 26 2009 	Review of the Rain Man suite.	This is strictly a review of the Rain Man Suite at Caesars, where I recently stayed for a bachelor party. This suite was based on the fictional one in the movie "Rain Man". Per the Las Vegas Sun, the suite in "The Hangover" was also partly based on this room. It's on the 69th floor (top floor) of the Forum Tower. The suite is bi-level, and has up to 4 bedrooms (if you use the connecting neighboring rooms). We used one of the connecting rooms, so we had 3 bedrooms and 3.5 bathrooms.The living room is huge. It has a circular sofa on both sides, and a 52" HDTV in the middle of the room that revolves 360 degrees. There is a great 2-story view of the Strip. There are speakers built into the ceilings and walls on both floors, and you can attach your IPod and blast your music through-out the entire suite. The TV also has access to both DirecTV and Dish Network, and there's also a Blu-Ray player in the room.There is a fancy remote that controls all the lighting (different moods), and the curtains. The suite also has a dining table and kitchen area. The bedrooms on the top level are huge, and have luxurious bathrooms. There are even TVs built into the bathroom mirrors. Because you need to be able to watch SportsCenter while you are shaving.The Suite is just awesome. We got numerous comments from other riders when we hit the 69 button on the elevator. One girl even jokingly accused me of trying to impress her by hitting that button. A few other people asked us for tours. Aug 20 2009 	Great stay at Caesars!	I stayed at CP with 3 of my girl friends, aged 24-25 from July 2  July 5, 2009. The walk from the room to the strip was about 10 minutes. In terms of restaurants, we ate at Noodle 9  it was fairly priced but the food not the greatest. I wouldnt recommend it. There is a food court between the casino and the Forum Shops  you could get good food for reasonable prices, and not have to go to a sit down restaurant. Highly recommend the burger place as the food is fresh and delicious!The pool at CP is very nice  you need to get out there before 11am in order to get lounge chairs for your group. And even so, this took some effort in moving lounge chairs around so that we could all sit together. By afternoon guests spread out on the deck wherever they can find space! The pool is great b/c it gets sun ALL day, vs other hotels where the sun might be blocked by the hotel during certain times.I probably wouldnt stay here again, only because there are so many other great hotels along the strip that you could probably get for a similar price  its always good to try something new!

Aug 20 2009 	Caesars Nice 	As with all stays there are Pros and Cons! Be prepared for LONG, LONG check-in lines. Our room had last been inhabited by a bachlorette party and their balloons were still up in the room We found more behind the couch. Serendipity is right out the front on the second level outside.The show was great Bette Midler stuff but I was disappointed in the audience. I had seen Bette 33 years ago at Caesars and that audience rocked. We were on the front row and we had four people next to us in shorts who kinda scowled during the whole show. There were booths where you could play 21 with an automated/televised dealer. That was fun. And there is a Rapid Roulette which gets rid of all the shoving at the tables. You have your own roulette table TV screen and about 40 seconds to place a min bet. That was fun too.The slots were tight BUT find the old machines and these pay out better. EVERYONE was playing penny slots. I don't get that. The casino was very very smokey and cocktail waitresses were overworked. With as much money as they are raking in downstairs you would think it would be free.Even though this trip was great, I would probably stay somewhere else next time. I am intrigued by the whole Fremont St. experience and the efforts hotels like the Golden Nugget are making to attract customers. So, might try that next time.If you want a great old time Vegas hotel with great amenities, this is the place.

Aug 13 2009 	Average not "super fancy" etc. as told	Im a little bit confused, how people rate this hotel as "super" or "great", or other synonyms describing how wondeful this hotel is. Maybe this is because some of the review makers have been only in few hotels and has not been travelling too much - or maybe the hotel rooms are all very different from each other, these are the only reasons I can think of.For my opinion, this hotel is a little worn out, and has certainly seen its best days. The public areas, as the lobby and the casino, have had their shining star times long ago. The carpets look old, and the service in front desk is poor.When we arrived the hotel (late at night) with our friends, we were asking to be located to the same floor (we both couples had forum tower de luxe rooms), but this could not be arrenged. Ok, I understand that in a big hotel full of guests this can be hard. But the thing really surprised me was that the clerk at the front desk gave us our keys and guided us to our rooms through the longest way - through the whole casino. He propably thought that we would be more anxious to come back down stairs to play in the casino, than if he would guided us to go via the shortest way to our rooms. I just found this irritating.By the way, no chance having the bell boy taking your luggage to your room- you have to do it your self...at least if you dont have to change the rooms you were just given...then you can get the bell boy carry your suitcases, at least this was our experience.When we got to our room, I first discovered dirty towels on the floor. As I walked through the room, there were two dirty wine glasses and an empty bottle of wine, and other trash lying on floor, on the bed and on the table. Also the bed was obviously used. Disgusting.I called the front desk immediately to have an other room. And I had to call there 4 times before anything happened. We were waiting with our lugagge in the dirty room for 35 minutes before somebody came. With a long way back to the reception and with 3 big suitcases in the middle of the night, that was really the only option - to wait. After several hours travelling in the middle of the night, it didnt feel nice at all. Well, the bell boy finally came, with new keys to our new room - in to a new floor again. He was terribly sorry, and really nice. He was shocked how we were given this dirty room, and said that this wasnt the only time this sort of thing had happened. When we got to the new room, he checked it first, and let us in after looking that everything was OK in the room. He was really nice, and the only person that apologised for the inconvenience.The next day I went to the front desk to say that I found last night waiting and poor service from the front desk terrible, and were given free of charge for 30 dollars of the drinks from the minibar. OK, thats fair enough, I thought.Well, that would been just too easy - as we cheked out later on, again an other clerk at the reception accused us to have been taken some nuts from the minibar, which I told was impossible, as myself and my spouse are terribly allergic to nuts! And yes, we had noticed that when you move or touch the minibar goods, they go wright away to your check, so we didnt even touch anything else than the drinks that we were having (and the nuts were in a different place, not even in the fridge!)- free of charge up to the 30 dollars given. Well, finally they believed us, and said its OK. For me, this was just another experience of the poor service in this hotel.Our friends room was otherwise OK, except the smelling of cigarettes & tobaccos in their room.They have Forum Shops mall area in the hotel, which was nice and convenient. Also a lot of restaurants to choose from. Casino was average. The hotel is very good situated.We went elsewhere for breakfast, as having heard some bad reviews of the hotels own breakfast buffet, so we didnt try that at all - so cant comment on that one.Las Vegas was nice, and we might go back some day, but definitely to an other hotel. This is not a 5 star hotel. I would give it 3 stars, average. Some improvement to the service and the public areas, and some promptness to service, and this hotel could be much better.

It takes forever to get around there or to get from your room to the strip. Check in was pretty quick and the staff there were very friendly. My room was comped but I don't think I would stay there again if I had to pay. We have stayed at just about all the Harrah's properties and while CP is beautiful, we enjoy ourselves just as much, if not more, at their other properties. The pool area is still under construction but we did enjoy our time spent by the pools. We stayed by the main pool most of the time and enjoyed it. We did not order any drinks due to the high prices and chose to drink just before or after going to the pool.We did not eat once at CP as they were so much more expensive than neighboring casinos and the reviews have not shown me that they are justified charging those higher prices. our Friends ate at Ogdens and spent about $400 on dinner. They said it was really good but not sure if they would ever do it again. Did not have any luck in the CP casino. So ventured off and hit just about every hotel on the strip the first two nights. We wound up hitting Slots of Fun two nights in a row. It was so much fun to be able to play with actual quarters or dollars on the slot machines so we hit there twice. There is something about that place that is fun. Circus Circus apparently took over ownership of Slots of fun on July 1st so I hope they keep things the same. It is nice to see that on the strip amongst all the giants that are there.We also ventured downtown for a day and had much more luck playing down town. Was disappointed to see the downtown mall is closed up. Looks like it had just closed in June as there were posters for the movie theatre of movies that came out this past June. I saw Dodge Ball there for the 1st time a few years ago with my kids on a past trip so I was bummed to see that it closed.After spending some time at the Golden Nugget, I think we may stay there next trip. Some times I really enjoy spending time downtown and they have the best pool area so that is next on my list.I can't wait to go back to Las Vegas!!!

Jul 27 2009 	Rooms in oldest sections a little "tired" and only "some" staff are responsive to your complaints	We got a room for a week in one of the older (cheapest) sections and you can tell the rooms are dated. Our one sink in the bathroom did not drain very well, but we put up with that for the first day. However, by day #2, we noticed that if you tried to shower at an "off time" like at 2PM (or any time later than the "usual" morning shower time) the water NEVER got beyond "luke warm"! When we called down to the desk to complain, we felt the desk person "blew us off". The person on the phone acted as though he really did not care, told us they would send someone up to "check it out" (they never did) and it was no better the 3rd. day! After another day of lukewarm water for a shower during an "off time", we stopped down stairs at the desk on our way out for the day and complained to a woman behind the desk. She was really very nice and responsive and told us that because they felt bad that out first 3 days were less than what we should have experienced in Ceasars Palace, they would upgrade us for no extra charge to another room in another tower. They even moved our luggage from the old room to the new room while we were out for the day. The new room in a new tower was very obviously an upgrade and we were very pleased at how this woman had handled it. Perhaps the man we spoke with the day before on the phone was not as responsive or perhaps the lesson is to walk down to the desk and speak directly to someone!! Anyway, the rest of the visit in this hotel was very good. If you can avoid staying in the older (cheapest) rooms, I would advise that. But, because of how well that one woman at the desk handled our complaint, I would still advise staying here since the location is just great.

Jul 27 2009 	Thank god for the complimentary upgrade.	Stayed at Caesar's for a three-day meeting, and the rate couldn't be beat. After checking into my room on the 15th floor, I found out why. It was dirty, nasty, and the cleaning staff had obviously lacked attention to detail (see pictures of the holes in the wall, cracked tissue box, missing light bulb, and the tellingly-stained desk chair). The deadbolt on the door didn't work, either.At first I thought I could stand it. Then I waited for two hours to get a new lightbulb and the lock fixed. But I couldn't take my eyes off that gross chair. I went down to the front desk armed with my pictures, and they upgraded me to a gorgeous suite. Thank god.

Jul 27 2009 	Amazing Hotel	I'm not sure why there are even any negative reviews at all... I'd like to say that I absolutely one hundred and 10 percent loved our hotel and our room. First of all, the location is PRIME, it is on the mid - strip location, right next to the Bellagio and VERY close to Paris and Planet Hollywood, and on the other side, the Mirage... I think the location itself is ideal, as most other hotels lie south or north of the strip and can be a good walk to get to. I personally enjoyed Caesars decor and just the hotel itself better than the inside of the Bellagio and certain other ones, you tend to find that most look alike inside (casino areas, etc). We were fortunate enough to get upgraded to the Palace Tower, even though I had booked a Forum Tower, and I didn't even have to ask, she just implied that we had booked the Palace Tower (which is one of the newest towers). We arrived fairly late, at about 11:30 so there virtually was no line to check-in (during the day the line is pretty long... this is a big hotel, so it's expected).Furthermore, the room was amazing. Big king sized bed, the views of the pool (Palace Tower is right next to the pools) and the bathroom had a nice big sized jetted tub in it as well. Also, there is construction going on in the pool area, however, much to many complaints I have seen, I didn't think the construction bothered us at all, they play music and it kind of surpasses the construction noise, I thought. Also, it does get pretty full, we went right when they opened at 8:30 (it's GREAT at this time because you get to pick where to sit, ample options, and the heat isn't unbearable). The pool area was by far my favorite of the hotel, very classy and nice. Also, we had breakfast at Augustus' Cafe (about 36 total for 2 people) and it was probably the best breakfast I've ever had! (No joke)Taxis to and from the airport to this location on the strip are about $12-15, so not bad at all. All in all, this hotel far exceeded my expectations, and you'll LOVE it!!! ENJOY!

Jul 25 2009 	Love it	We loved the room,.and we got a great deal. There was a nice jacuzzi in the room - love it.Staff were friendly, buffet was nice. Great swimming pool, but was crowded because it was summer.
Jul 25 2009 	stayed for a great rate	surprised at reasonable rate, went to restaurants and shops, saw rest of strip hotels.lv was better than we thought it might be.

Jul 22 2009 	Nice clean friendly staff the place to stay on the strip	Booked for $130 a night mid-week. Got an upgrade by asking Justin at the front desk, got a nice suite a little larger overlooking the pool/26th floor. Rooms are beautiful, nice beds, lots of pillows, lots of towels in the bathroom, huge shower, jacuzzi tub. maybe a 32" lcd tv minimal programming.Nice restaurants, lots of affordable shops, casino is classy. Spotless everywhere.The Pure Club goes off 7 nights a week, mostly hip-hop rap with some rock thrown in, mostly a 20's club. The pussycat gambling area has nice staff and is located next to the club and poker room.I just can't say enough nice things about this hotel, valet parking was reasonable retrieve.Now the cons: yes they are doing renovations on the west side of the pool. Minimal noise and intrusion, if this bothers you ask for a room facing the strip or north or south.Pools are nice, the lap pool is warmer, get there early to snake some lounge chairs, or reserve a monster poolside bed or cabana.EZ walk to NY, bellagio, mgm, planet hollywood-from there take the e-train to luxor/mandalay which is the south strip.I did not get a chance to eat at buffets, however as always SOuth Point is the best priced on the strip for large groups or families that can drive 5 minutes.

Jul 22 2009 	AWESOME ROOM - BRING LOTS OF MONEY FOR FOOD!!!	My husband, daughter (12 yrs. old) and I arrived at McCarran from Newark around 11:30 am - bumpy flight. We were picked up by Presidential Limo (stretch). Very nice! Stopped at liquor store on way for supplies.Room: 5 Nights Comped at Forum Tower Deluxe (thanks to my Atlantic City Harrah's Play).Upon arrival at Caesar's, there had to be about 50 people in the check-in line....so the wait began. Finally, I "tipped" the check-in clerk $25 to get an upgrade from our Forum Tower Deluxe room to an Augustus Tower Deluxe Room (we had a great view of the Bellagio Fountains! Room 3782).We had a refrigerator brought up (free of charge) and unpacked. Walked around hotel a bit....ate some lunch at Augustus Cafe and had a very nice lunch (expensive, though).Gambling Highlights: Played mostly 3-card poker, VP, and Blackjack. Went up and down on the table games, although I did get three "6's" - the sign of the beast, which paid 30 to 1 on my $25 bet. Not too bad, but I ended up giving it back eventually. VP machines at Caesars were scarce, so I played at the VP Bar by the Sportsbook. They sure know how to pour drinks over there....I don't remember getting back to the room that night....and YES I LOST AGAIN!I did have fun and met some nice people. My husband played in a few poker tourneys, didn't win either. We have a curse with Harrah's properties, as we never win at any of them (even in Atlantic City). We are good with Boyd/MGM though. Went to Bellagio and won $250 within 5 minutes on a $.25 slot! Go figure!Food: Went to Bellagio Buffet. Had to have the giant Alaskan King Crab Legs and the Prime Rib. Excellent! We all got our money's worth that night for sure!Caesar's Food Court: Beware! Food isn't bad, but God forbid you want a slice of pepperoni pizza, you'll pay $6.50 for it! Or how about $4 for one bagel?Rao's: Inside Caesar's. Very nice meal - excellent food. It should be for $160.00 (without liquor)!Otherwise, ate at Caesar's Cafe Lago Buffet for breakfast only. I heard it sucked and it sure did. Awful - stay away. The eggs were runny, no selection, too expensive, etc.Mostly went to the Payard Pattisere coffee shop for breakfast sandwich/coffee. Ate at BLT Burger at Mirage one night - very good food and reasonably priced!Went to Joe's Prime Steak and Stone Crab on our last night (Fri.) for our 15th anniversary. Excellent steak and crab! Yes, you sure do pay for it, but the food/service is excellent. I think I saw a few celebrities there as well!POOL: The pool at Caesar's is still under construction. You don't hear the noise too much, as they play loud music. 2 main pools are open, but we pretty much stayed by the round main one. No, there was no styrofoam or dust or dirt from the construction in the pool at all. Get there before 9:00 for decent seats. It opens at 8:00 a.m.Tip: Don't order a beer at the pool - it's $8 for one, or $18 for a frozen drink. Ouch! We learned early and brought water most of the time.Fun: I had to take my daughter to the NY/NY Rollercoaster or I would never hear the end of it. $28 later, we rode it (I shut my eyes the whole time - I don't like heights!). We went to their arcade, Rainforest Cafe for lunch at MGM Grand.I took my daughter across street to Flamingo Wildlife Habitat - Nice birds, turtles, Koi fish! Went shopping.Went to the Dirk Arthur Extreme Magic Show at Tropicana - very nice magic show with Lions. Good value at $30, as well! QUA SPA: I had my husband booked for a massage for his early birthday present. They run a $99 special Sun - Wed. with full use of the spa/gym all day and a massage. He enjoyed it up until the end when he slipped and fell in the steam room. He hurt his back. They did fill out accident report, but that's about it. No follow up calls to see how he was doing or anything. I did enjoy the spa baths and steamrooms (especially the artic ice room), however.Thus, with my husband layed up with a hurt back, we couldn't go see Love as we had wanted to. Next time for sure. He's feeling much better now!So, that pretty much sums it up! Much drinking, gambling with little wins, a couple of nice restaurants, alot of pool time, and the token arcade/magic show for the little one. We all had a good time and Caesar's took an extra $150 off the final bill in comps~!
Jul 22 2009 	STILL AMAZING	Its location still makes this the best hotel in vegas.And dont be put off by the renovations ,this is still the BEST pool in VEGAS.

Jul 22 2009 	Stay only for the location	Caesar's is an ok place to stay, but I certainly wasn't blown away by anything there. I've had better service other places. We were given an upgraded room, but had to switch rooms and were downgraded again. We were there for a conference and I think its hard to go to Vegas for a conference, because you have to be up at 6 am to attend. We ended up having to switch rooms because we were on a nonsmoking floor and there was a HUGE party of young men in the room across the hallway smoking like chimney's in their room and Security wouldn't do anything about it. They were also in and out ALLLLL NIGHT LONG. Which is to be expected in Vegas so we couldn't really hold it against them for having a good time. But, we could not sleep with the smoke and noise and had to ask to be moved. EVERYTHING is a ripoff at Caesar's. If you stay, make sure you have deep pockets. I need not bore you with the details. Rooms were VERY CLEAN. We stayed in the forum tower. Housekeeping was good/friendly. The elevators are nice and quick...never had to wait. The location is one of the best on the strip, but I think I would try another hotel in the same area next time. I don't think it is worth the price because who wants to be in their room in vegas anyway?Pool construction is still going on, but there are a couple of pools open.
Jul 21 2009 	great place	Fantastic hotel. Brilliant location for exploring the strip. So many amenities with great shopping and eating at the Forum Shops.

Jul 20 2009 	Fantastic Visit	We always stay across the street at Harrah's and thought we'd try Caesar's this time. I was comped 3 nights stay and given a room in Classic Tower. After reading poor reviews on the Classic rooms I asked for an upgrade. We were given a beautiful room on the 68th (of 69 ) floor with a strip view. We had a few meals at the Cafe Lafo Buffet; not too many choices for the price. Overall great trip! Treated very well.

Jul 18 2009 	Nothing Special!	Stayed at Caesar's Palace for three nights. The only reason I stayed at Caesar's was because we got a fantastic deal. Enjoyed my stay, however I would likely not stay here again unless it was super cheap. Here are the pros & cons in my opinion:Pros:- Spacious Room- Jacuzzi Tub in Room- Clean- Overall, great customer service.- Toileteries replaced everydayCons:- Long line-ups upon check-in- Pool under construction, you can't relax by the poolside due to the jackhammers!- Takes forever to exit the casino/hotel because the towers are far away from the entrance/exit- No mini bar/fridge in room- Late checkout only 1 hour later- Noisy AC unitOverall, I enjoyed my stay. It served it's purpose to sleep and shower while we were in Vegas. However, I prefer smaller sized hotel where you don't need to walk 10 mins just to get outside.

Jul 16 2009 	Relaxation Heaven	I have been coming to Vegas several times a year for over eight years and I stayed at Caesar's for the first time on this trip. I was able to register early and after I asked the desk clerk upgraded me to a beautiful room in the Augustus Tower with a view of the Bellagio Fountains. If you can manage a room in this fairly new tower DO IT. The jetted tub was sensational, the bed heavenly and room service was prompt and pretty reasonable. There is a 5.00 service fee and an automatic 18% gratuity so it may not be for everyone, but I was traveling alone and so it was fine. The Cafe Lago breakfast buffet is good but limited. The coffee was great though. The best part of the whole trip was Qua Baths. There is a 45.00 entry fee per day, but it entitles you to the use of the workout facility and the incredible spa for the whole day. If you use a spa service (Salon services like pedicures do not count) use of the facilities is included. I had a massage - ask for Kira M., she was really terrific. All in all it was a wonderful visit and I will be making Caesars Palace my new destination in Vegas.

Jul 15 2009 	All hail Caesar!	Our experience at Caesars Palace probably made this the best Vegas Vacation we have taken.Location  Best location on the strip, about midway up. Next to Bellagio, across the street from the Flamingo, which means the Venetian or MGM is only a 10 minute walk away. Even if you dont like the casino at Caesars, you are very close to a range of others. And if shows are your thing, there is a half price tix booth right across the street at Bills. Check-in  We checked in at 1:15am (thanks crazy reduced airline schedules!), but this seemed to work to our advantage; the line was non-existent (just one person in front of us), and we got a free upgrade! The staff member was on the computer for 5 minutes or so with the occasional apology for the delay, but then declared that the rooms werent coming up so he upgraded us! We booked the Classic Room, but got an Augustus Tower room (needless to say, this review might have been different if we had got the room we paid for!). Staff member at reception was very polite and helpful despite the late hour. Worth noting that when we passed reception at other times, lines were huge, so if you are arriving at an earlier hour, bring a book. Room  Augustus Tower Rooms are marvelous! The dcor is modern, with just enough hints of the Roman theme to fit without being tacky. The view was of the strip and the mountains, if you looked to the side of the window  otherwise straight ahead was just the roofs of the casino buildings (they should really think about putting solar panels on them  such a waste of space!). The bed was very comfortable, room was clean. Nice sofa and armchairs, so when relaxing one doesnt have to sit on the bed like a teenager in his room. Closet had a safe, robes and slippers. The bathroom had twin sinks (always a wife-pleaser), a separate small room for the toilet, a TV and separate bath and shower, with the bath being a whirlpool bath! After reading reviews on this site I didnt even touch the mini-bar fridge for fear of false billing. TV had a nice selection of channels, and was a new LCD. Restaurants  Every time we went past most of the restaurants, there was a line, so we ate elsewhere. Amenities  Casino is a nice size, but didnt have a lot of Video Poker (our game of choice) so we ended up not gambling here at all. Have gambled here in the past, but there is just something that doesnt make it appealing. Didnt use the pools, so no comment on them. We did however use the Qua Spa, and I have to say it is phenomenal! You can use the gym for $25, or the whole facility for $45  I recommend the $45 day pass! I was shown the facilities and given a locker, as well as robe and slippers, then set off for the gym. The gym is very well equipped and compares favorably to some private gyms, let alone the usual sad excuse for a hotel gym. Post workout, your options are incredible  plan to spend a whole afternoon here! Sauna, steam room (so steamy I couldnt see anything beyond 2 feet), steam room with eucalyptus, and a cold room, with moisturizing snow! There is a hot tub, as well as roman mineral baths, of different temperatures. Showers have body wash, shampoo and conditioner in them as standard. Once done, you can shave in the well lit bathroom (shaving gel and razors provided), then relax in the tea room, which has a large TV showing ESPN, magazines for men, a range of five different fancy teas, as well as snacks, fruit and choices of water or juices. At no point did I feel pressured to leave or hurry up. If the rest of your vacation involves late nights, drinking and over-indulging this is the perfect recovery for you. The only time I got a bit miffed was with the staff at the gift shops, who really didn't seem interested in serving someone who only wanted to buy a postcard, to the point where I just walked out the first one after waiting a ridiculous amount of time. Checkout  I checked the bill online through the hotel TV, and there was almost no wait at reception to get a copy of the bill and hand the keys in. Bill was correct, staff very friendly. Overall, the best experience at a hotel in Vegas so far. If you are one of those picky people that want fresh soap every day, and new towels and your slightest whim at a moments notice, then you may be disappointed. As someone that just wants a nice clean room, working amenities and a correct bill, I was very happy.

Jul 14 2009 	Great Place to Stay!!!	Three friends and I traveled to Vegas because one of us was attending a conference. The rest of us piggy backed on his room. At check in we were offered an upgrade but due to using "company" funds he declined. Once we arrived in the "Romar Tower" room we promptly exited and went back for the upgrade. There's a reason there are no pictures of this room on Ceasar's website. It looked like a Motel 6 room. Once back at the check in desk we asked for the before mentioned upgrade. The clerk had already assigned that room so she gave us an even bigger room in the "Augustus Tower", for the same price as the smaller room. Lets just say we made a good decision. The room was clean, well furnished, great view, and we all slept well with no outside noise heard. As with most rooms in vegas, there was no coffee maker, no fridge, etc. Stay away from the food and drink bar. If you lift an item out of it's place, a sensor is alerted and you will be charged. We had to get creative when icing down our beer. The beds were very comfortable and AC worked very good. WiFi in the room is $15.00 a day.The restaurants at Ceasar's are very expensive, $77.00 ribeye is a bit much. We only ate at Ceasar's for breakfast, in the food court. Average price for a 3 egg omelet, 4 pieces of toast, potatoes, and large coffee was $14.00. A little high but we couldn't eat all we were served. We did have a late night bacon cheesburger combo one night, same food court, $15.00, and it too was huge. Very good food as well. I utilized the workout facilities for the three of the four days while there. It's normally $25.00 a day but they had a 3 days for $50.00 deal which was o.k. The gym was clean and the equipment was new but it lacked somewhat in space. It has a very small area for the hand weights and free weights. Other than that I was able to get a good workout in.If you plan on getting some sun by the pool, plan on getting down there before 1000 a.m. If you don't, you'll find yourself walking in circles waiting on a chair to open. Even though it was crowded the chairs are only 3 rows deep in most areas so it wasn't too bad. Drinks at the pool are around $12.00 for 12 ounce and $19.00 for 16 ounce. Some kids but not alot. That"s important to me as I don't want to listen to a bunch screaming and crying while lounging. Spoke to a security guard who told us that two additional pools are supposed to open in Aug. 09 but they may be running a bit behind. That would bring the total to 5 pools. The slots paid pretty well at Ceasar's. Three out of four of us took extra cash home from the slots. Can't speak for the blackjack tables or poker.All in all the hotel is very clean and well maintained. No complaints about any of the staff. Plenty of bar maids both in the casino and at the pool. I'm already planning another trip in Sept. of this year and I will be staying at Ceasar's Palace.

Jul 12 2009 	Treated as a valued customer.	After an initial wait on the priority line (as a Platinum Reward Member), with those with the Gold card being taken ahead of me despite the intent of the PRIORITY line, the service was quick and supportive. The staff on initial registration and sign out were efficient, polite, and helpful. Although I was not placed in the wing I initially booked a room in, the room I received had a wonderful view. Even as a solo traveller, I felt safe and at ease. I will definitely stay at Caesars again and will recommend it to friends and family members - based on my experience. BTW - I even treated myself to a hair salon treatment (coloring) with my long time earned points and was again treated with respect.

Jul 12 2009 	Okay Stay	I stayed here for 2 nights as part of my nine day stay and did enjoy it. The rooms were comfortable but a little dirty. The bathroom was awesome had a shower and bathtub separate. There was construction going on at the pool that was annoying couldn't relax. Lots of slots to choose from on the casino floor. Good drink service and nice costumes. The shops were fun lots and lots of them top of the line. I probaly would not stay here again but it was not bad I just didn't feel that comfortable there.

Jul 11 2009 	If you are going for the pool......wait a while	Can't beat some of the rates in Vegas right now so we couldn't resist a quick week vacation. We picked Caesars Palace for it's great mid-strip location (we didn't plan to really leave the strip and did not want to rent a car). Here's how we found it:Location = Mid-strip can't beat it. You will do a lot of walking with thousands of complete strangers but....that's Vegas. The hotel is HUGE, lots and lots of walking so bring the right shoes.Rooms = We upgraded to the Palace tower upon arrival for an additional $25.00 a night. This is the closest tower to the pool and that was one of main reasons for going. The room was very spacious as was the bathroom, excellent jacuzzi tub and separate shower. We heard horror stories about the Roman tower and wanted to avoid it at all costs.Housekeeping = top notch, room was kept very clean and no personal items were disturbed.Prices = Food and drink are not cheap at Caesars; the food court is the best bet where most meals were about $10.00 each. Soft drinks at the pool are $3 to $4 a piece. Alcohol at the bars is armed robbery, one night my wife and I each had a simple shot and it was $30.00 for both!Pools = You may have heard the pools are being upgraded or rather new additions. They are in the process of adding new pools and finishing construction on a new tower and meeting facilities.....all of this is around the pool. Dust and construction noise surround 50% of the pool area and you can't help but notice them. The pool chairs fill up on the early side, we were at the pool by 8am and had no problem but by 11am you were out of luck. There are two main pools available now with a 3rd "European" pool available for an extra charge. Not enough chairs for the crowd that hits the area so get there early if you want to sit.Bottom line; nice and big place pick the right tower and wait a few months if you plan on spending time at the pool.

Jul 10 2009 	Perfact Vacation!!!	I had a great package deal at Travelocity (I booked about 6 week advance) for this hotel.Upon check-in, I asked the very friendly desk clerk if I can get any complimentary upgrades, and she upgraded us to a Forum Tower, which is one of newly innovated tower - everything in the room were cleannnnn!! If you don't ask, you will not get it. Don't ever touch anything in the fridge in your room, eventhough you don't open, they scan things that removed and charge you for it.We did not try the restaurents in this hotel (very expensive, but I am sure they are good), but we tried at Beijing Noodle 9. If you like a chiness food, you got to try! Handmade noodle and dumpling are just perfact! Average entry costs for 12-18 dollors. *** Try at "KOKOMOS" at Mirage Hotel - they have Pre Fixed Menu (you have to ask) for 29.99, and it was amazing!!! 3 course meal, nice atmosphere, good food.***Sushi Roku at Forum Shop - the best fresh sushi I never had. Try live sweet shrimp, the best!!!You will not see any $5 table game in this hotel. The lowest table I saw was $15. Most of them are $25 min.Shopperholic? Forum Shop got everything (all expensive designer handbags and cloth...you know the deal) I will recomand the Prime Outlet Mall - great deals on nice brand names.Overall, we just had stay at Caesars Palace and we will definately go back!

Jul 10 2009 	Wow!	I had taken an early flight and arrived at Caesars at 10:30am. I was somewhat concerned because I knew that check-in was at 3:00pm. There were perhaps a half dozen folks also attempting to check-in early.The woman at the front desk was very friendly and accomodating. She was able to find me a room (and EVEN upgraded it at no cost). I was in the Palace Tower right near the pool. This was perhaps the easiest tower to get to. You must walk through the rather smokey casino to get to the elevator.I was on the 20th floor and my room faced the Strip towards the right and mountains to the left. Wow! The room was huge. The furniture was modern, but simple. The king bed had very comfortable sheets, pillows and comforter..lots of huge pillows. The matress was firm, but not too hard. The air conditioner system worked flawlessly. The thermostat is on the wall, my room was hot when I arrived so I cooled it down to 70 and it only took about 15 minutes to achieve this.The bathroom was about the size of my living room.A stall shower, two sinks and a sunkin jacuzzi. I had no idea where the toilet was. Aha, it was behind the door and included a phone. The tv was flat screen and received an impressive amount of channels.A robe was included in the closet. The toiletries had a tangy, orange scent. I loved the lotion.There was an ipod docking unit/radio, but the docking did not work and the radio only picked up a few stations. High speed internet cost $14.95 per 24 hour. At times the internet was quite slow.The room was incredibly quiet. I never heard a door slam or noise from another room.It was very clean. My only objection was the maid walking into my room at 9:00am and didn't even knock. I guess she must have assumed that I was still out partying/gambling. You can check the cost you have accrued to your room on the hotel's tv channel. In addition, you can check out after 6:00am utilizing the hotel tv channel.The casino is large and perhaps one of the more sought out on the strip. I have heard that many people come over to Caesars to play the slots and cards. The casino floor went on and on and on. Unlike Atlantic City (which has smoking sections), smoking is everywhere! Even if you just walk through the casinos on your way to somewhere else, you are bound to get smoke blown in your face.After you leave the casino you are immersed in a huge shopping area with some of the most upscale shoppes in Vegas. The stores go on and on and you can get lost trying to navigate from one side to the other. The price of a Coach purse actually was higher then it would have been at Macy's, but I'll always remember where I bought it. The ceiling is a distinct blue and the area is very posh and made to look like a Roman street. Caesars is one of the largest hotels and it takes about 2 days to figure out how to get from point A to point B. There is a LOT of walking involved. Some times I found it easier to exit and walk outside then maneuver the massive maze.The Coliseam is the theatre where the top stars like: Cher and Bette Midler play. I saw Bette and had wonderful seats and she put on an impressive show.The pool is waist deep(so don't expect to be able to swim). It is a large circle surrounded by fountains and sculptures of caesar. There is contruction going on near the pool (a new tower is being added). The music at the pool was so loud, it drowned out any of the construction noise.There were many young people when I was there in the pool and nearly all had drinks in their hands. It was hot and the pool was crowded. If you want to get some exercise, you can actually walk around the pool a few times.You have to get down early because the lounge chairs get filled up quickly. I tried to get my space staked out between 930-1030am. Those who came in the area after 1100 did not have much luck finding a place to lounge. There is also a "European" pool located just outside of the doors.This is an adult-only pool area and the women can go topless.The waitress/bar staff at the pool are agonizingly slow. I ordered a drink and it arrived about 45 mins. later. It just appears that they do not have the adequate amount of staff to services a large crowd.I treated myself to a massage near the pool (in the shade) for $50 for a half hour. The masseuse was fantastic and very friendly.The pool store is very overprised. Unless you want to pay $12-$15 for suntan lotion (bring your lotion from home). Soda's cost over $2.00 a bottle and snacks range from $2.00-$4.00.There are loads of restaraunts, but they are quite expensive. I ate one large meal at the Japanese restaraunt (which I was told had among the best sushi in Vegas). The sushi was by far among the best I have ever had, fresh and tasteful. The cost was $25.00 for two rolls.One word to describe the Caesars staff--Accomodating.The cost of the stay was well worth it.

Jun 23 2009 	Disappointing a real shame!!!	I have travelled to Vegas a number of times for leisure and business, I have stayed in Caesars palace in 2007 and had a wonderful time.On this occasion I went with my husband and parents, brother and family and said that Ceasars had been a really nice place to stay so we all booked in! Jun 18 2009 	A Great Location For Our Stay in Las Vegas	We stayed in Las Vegas during Memorial Day weekend, May 22nd through the 27th at Caesars, which was our first trip. (Well actually it was almost 30 years for me, so I might as well say it was my first trip!) We had a choice for any comped room in the HET properties, so we decided to stay at Caesars for the location, and pool facilities. I must say, I was not disappointed with the hotel, nor was I totally satisfied. It was okay, but I would probably stay somewhere else next time we go.We arrived Friday night, landing about 10:00pm. We got our car, and proceeded to WalMart to buy a coffee pot. (They actually charge per night for a coffee pot, so we bought one for $10.00 and left it in the room when we checked out.) The walk from the self park to check in seemed endless. Yes, this hotel is enormous! I thought people were exaggerating, or didnt like to walk, but they really werent kidding! My suitcase handle broke during transit, so it was difficult trying to drag the suitcase on the carpeting throughout the casino trying to find the registration desk. By the time we got to the hotel, it was already 12:00 midnight (3:00 am EST), so maybe I was a little tired and testy too. After doing the research on Trip Advisor, I reserved the Forum Tower above the Classic Room, and was a little apprehensive that we would lose this room due to the late check-in, especially since it was comped. But to our surprise, they up-graded us to the Palace Towers, 20th floor. The room was okay, had a nice unobstructed view, and we still received our requests of king bed/smoking. The bathroom was large, with a Jacuzzi tub, but we never used it. The employees were very friendly, going out of their way to say good morning and chitchat a bit. I have no complaints about the staff and housekeeping.The thing that I really did not care for, was how the hotel nickel and dimes its customers. I already mentioned the coffee maker, which annoyed me a little, but when we checked in they told us about the amenities/stocked refrigerator in the room. They said that everything is scanned, and even if you just pick something up and look at it, your room will be charged. Needless to say, we steered way away from all of these items for fear of knocking something down! I read this before on one of the reviews, but still, it was a bit disconcerting. They also charge per day to use the gym, but with all of the walking we did, the gym was not needed. Hotel Internet was also charged by the day, but my BF has an air card, so we did not need to purchase this. Since we did not pay for the room, I shouldnt complain about the extra charges. But had we paid regular price for the room, I would not have been happy at all!Both my BF and I did not care for the Casino at this hotel. It seems there are two areas for gambling, one area was mainly tables with some slot machines placed around, and the other area was the slot machine area. Neither my BF nor I play the table games; we play the slots and my BFs favorite is Keno. But at Caesars, they did not have the Keno machine he likes, so we spent most of our time out of the hotel. There was something about the layout neither one of us liked, and when I spoke to other people, they also felt the same. We spent a lot of time at Bills, which was right across the street. Kind of a locals type of place in the middle of the strip, and fun. For all the time we spent there, I only saw Big Elvis show once, at its tail end, but I think I would have really enjoyed seeing the whole thing. It was quite entertaining! The 99 cent Margaritas were pretty good too! Even though I picked this hotel for its pool area, we did not use it at all. In fact, we didnt even look at it! I read that part of the pool area was under construction. With that in mind, coupled with the occupancy at the hotel, I thought the pool area would be wall-to-wall people, and not very relaxing. But Vegas is not a place to relax! We were on the go constantly, and it was a good thing I brought comfortable walking shoes.I think the best thing about the hotel was the location. It was centrally located between the Bellagio, and the Mirage. The Forum Shops are connected, although we never walked through them. We rented a car, but hardly used it. I dont think we would get a car next time, unless we leave the city. The traffic was terrible; I think I could walk to most places faster. The last day we planned to go to the Lake Mead area, but found out that same day President Obama was staying at our hotel, which made for an even more chaotic atmosphere, and decided not to give up our prime parking spot. It must have been fate that we couldnt go, because my BF won the jackpot at Keno at the Bellagio!One day we drove to Fremont Street (the old Las Vegas), and I loved it! They are celebrating Summer of Love, the 60s. Blood, Sweat and Tears played during the afternoon, and they will have other relatively well known bands from the 60s playing there throughout the summer. They also had another band playing 60s rock, along with a jazz musician, and probably others that I missed. The light show was spectacular! I couldnt describe it, but it was of course 60s themed, and made the visit to Fremont worth the trip. That, and the 99 cent shrimp cocktails we had for lunch at one of the casinos.All in all, we had a really good time in Vegas. I did a lot of research, thanks to everyones input on Trip Advisor, so we were prepared with a list of things to do and see. We didnt have the time to do and see everything, and at times I felt I was on sensory overload, with only 5-6 hours of sleep. Im glad it was just my BF and me, because I think with more people, it would be too confusing, trying to coordinate times and desires. We spent about 4 full days there, and probably another day would have been good for us, being that it was our first trip. I guess we will have to plan another trip for next year!

Jun 18 2009 	Worth staying there if only for the spa and location.	We just back from our first trip to Vegas. This is a beautiful hotel, but the service could be better. After we had waited in a very long line to check in, one desk clerk beckoned us to her station, only to walk away. I wish we had taken her up on that, but I'll get to that later. Anyway, she wouldn't even pre-register us. The hairdryer in the room may as well have been someone with emphysema blowing on my hair, for all the power it had. And the shower - only a small soapdish for shelving. I had to put shampoo, conditioner, razor on the floor.The breakfast buffet at Cafe Lago was disappointing. Definitely go across to the Bellagio or Paris for their buffet.Casino: the dealers - except for the girls in the Pussycat Dolls casino, looked and acted miserable.Pool: lots of construction going on, but that didn't really affect our experience there. We could have spent God-knows-how-much on a sunbed or cabana, but we were on a budget. We ended up finding two chairs that were not even next to each other. That wouldn't have bothered me so much, except for the fact that no one ever asked us for our name, room key, or anything to prove we were hotel guests. I wonder how many of the people taking up the lounge chairs had no business being there in the first place.Spa: The only reason I'd go back to this hotel. Qua Baths and Spa is amazing! Awesome. Ask for him!Another cool thing is all the toiletries they provide for your after-treatment freshening up. All you need to bring is your make-up - they have everything else.Cool spa gift shop, too - with reasonably priced merchandise.All in all, the spa and the location keep this from being a bad review. Jun 18 2009 	Beware of the construction around the pools!!!!	Great hotel, I mean, c'mon it's Caesar's Palace!! Everything, food, casino, location, atmosphere) was awesome. Huge earth movers, air horns, beeping noises, etc. It was all clear as a bell. Once we got down to the pool area, which is very nice, we battled more noise, banging, rouge debris flying about, and dust. The construction even drowned out the killer music casinos play poolside. Oh, and this was my favorite, there were tiny pieces of styrafoam blown into the pools from the construction side. The little white pieces would form this huge mass, like something out of a movie, into a snake like creature and circle the pool. It reminded me of Red Tide scenario.Bottom line, hotel = great. You'll be in for a big disappointment, if you want to relax at the pool.

Jun 18 2009 	Incredible experience in a Palace Deluxe room	I had a great experience staying on a Hotwire-booked trip at Caesar's. I arrived at check-in around 1:30. I was told the official check-in time had not begun, but the woman at the front desk said she was able to find a room for me. It's a 26-inch LCD tv that did not display HD channels. The channel selection was good.The bathroom is incredible. A giant square mirror rests over two golden sinks, with a beautiful and deep tub to the right. There is a separate shower area which I appreciated, and the toilet is in a small room by itself. No tv in the bathroom. The bathroom's marble floors were the best part.The view from my window was of the incredible pool area below. Unfortunately, the pool was currently under construction so I had a good view of that. However, under normal circumstances, the view from my room would be superb, and I still enjoyed it myself. One negative thing about the room I can say is that it is not well lit, even during the daytime. I had all the lights and lamps on, and the blinds on the window fully open, and it was still rather dark in my room.
