I told them I had not taken them from the room and they promptly removed them from the bill.The casino at Caesar's is very good. I do not play many slots, but prefer poker, and Caesar's has one of the best poker rooms on the strip, if not the best. They have a pretty good selection of high- and low-level games throughout the casino, though I had some trouble finding a blackjack game during the middle of the day that wasn't a $25 minimum. As stated before, I had the minor problem at checkout, but other than that it was fine. The lines were short for me both checking in and out, and even during a peak check-in time (around 4:30) I only saw a line of about four people.I was very pleased with Caesar's, especially the room I got for the price I paid. I would gladly stay there again. It is a cut above the other 4-star hotels on the strip.

Jun 16 2009 	Ceasar's is disappointing in comparison to same or lower priced hotels	I just returned from Ceasar's Palace with a group of guys down in Vegas for a bachelor party. We were not traveling on a budget and frankly, without our women, we were more tolerant to problems. Here is honest balanced feedback of the hotel (can't stand people that find no positives):Check-in: Horrible. We arrived on Thursday night at 10PM and still waited 35 minutes due to the fact that there were only 3 people at the front desk. As well, we were told that there were tons of rooms with King sized beds available, but none with two beds. After ten minutes of explaining that non-gay guys on a bachelor party don't want to sleep with each other, we were told that there were some rooms that were vacant, and a rush could be put on them with housekeeping. Why would they not try to clean rooms with two beds earlier in the day to make them available? Anyway, we were told would need to come back in 2 hours. When we did, we had to wait another 25 minutes in the VIP line. The guys ahead of of in line were completely upset about the room they had been given and the guy behind us told us that he was livid with what he had been given. This validated for us that numerous people were having difficulty. On a positive note, check-out was a breeze, however the hotel was completely inflexible on having a late checkout....on a sunday! hahaRooms:Huge disappointment. We were given 3 rooms in the Roman Tower and they were 3 star quality. The beds and furniture were old and tired (the pictures on their website were definitely airbrushed to perfection as the reality is much different when you walk in the room). The bathroom would have been comparable to that of a motel.....and the clothes closet was located within the bathroom (have never seen this before). There were no minibar/fridges in the rooms. There really was no view of the strip from any of the rooms. Instead, we were staring at a bunch of pipes and maintenance buildings.Pool:Horrible. Not even close to enough pool lounge chairs for the size of the hotel. We had to grab single chairs from all over and start grouping them together in one location, but pool security got upset at that. When we told them that their lack of lounge chairs was ridiculous, they backed off and said they would allow it. There were hundreds of people that had no chairs and left the pool area frustrated or sat on the cement. On our second day, we decided to pay $30 each to go into the "Venus" adult pool area and avoid the deck chair hassle. Unbelievably, we got in there and there were no deck chairs at all. Basically, they wanted us to pay $1000 for a private cabana or sit on the cement on the edge of the pool. Shouldn't a $30/person pool entry fee implicitly mean that you would get a simple pool chair? Ridiculous! We ended up exiting the Venus pool to once again move a bunch of single chairs by the main pool and lost the $30/each.Location:Only good aspect of the hotel. It is right in the middle of the strip and there is some great shopping (The Forum Shops) attached to it.Service:Pool bar service was horrible. I felt bad for the waitresses because they were doing their best, but there was only two of them that we could see serving the entire pool of hundreds. We ordered large margaritas ($20 each) on the first day and it took 45 minutes for them to get to us. The lobby restaurant was poor as well. We went there for breakfast on the last morning. We were given our drinks and then it took them 20 minutes to come and take the rest of our order.Sidenotes:The Casino was fine, but you need to be ready to play higher wager tables. We ran into a few Vegas regular gamblers who were staying at other hotels and gambling at Ceasar's. We asked them why and they told us that Ceasar's used to be a great hotel, but since their new management took over they have let the hotel spiral downwards and become chincy. We couldn't have agreed more.All in all, you can get comparable prices for other hotels like MGM Grand, The Hotel @ Mandalay Bay, The Mirage....and fairly close prices for The Bellagio, The Venetian, Planet Hollywood, etc. The majority of us have previously stayed in Las Vegas at all of these hotels. Even The Luxor rooms are better than what you get at Ceasar's. TAKE MY ADVICE and stay at a comparably priced hotel that will have nicer rooms, a better pool, and better service.

Jun 13 2009 	Disappointed Customer Satisfaction	Just got back from Ceaser's Palace. I was not expecting the "less than expected" treatment. I was surprised that in this time of economic turmoil that one would "exceed customer expectation" considering 'Customers" are the reason they are employed. I stayed in late and requested housekeeping to turn my room and replenish it with new towels and sheets. I left for 1 hour and a half and I tried to come back to my room. My room card will not let me in. I had to walk back to the hotel registration desk and wait in a lengthy line just to "re-code" my card (20 minutes). I was irritated at that point. The desk clerk was dry, inhospitable and looked like he hated his job, no dialogue. After WAITING in line, I went back to my room, (which is in the Palace Towers, LONG WALK) I get in and my room had not been touched by anyone. I was really irritated now. I phoned for a supervisor, but got an automated system putting me on hold. Did I say I was irritated; I finally got a supervisor to re-tell my experience. They did listen, apologized and gave me a $50 food and beverage comp. Did I mention that youre in Vegas and everything is priced like you were shopping at a luxury retailer. I used the comp and got early breakfast as I was flying out before the sun came up in the am. The food was horrible. My daughter who is a juvenile makes better food, really. The pancakes were dry, overcooked. It had a decent size for the price ($12). The milk ($4) temperature felt like room temperature. My omelet ($15) was pretty normal. It took about 45 minutes to get it. Make sure you get ALL of the finer detail when you check-out. Because I did not use my "Players" card, my room was not comp'ed. I was suppose to spend a minimum of $100 for this, THEY DID NOT TELL ME and would not credit my bill. Oh, .and the Poker room does not count. I went and used my players card and met the minimum requirement, but still no satisfaction. I would suggest anyone staying anywhere else than Ceaser's Palace. Please do not go through this experience that I went through. We work hard for our money and they should too. Vegas is hurting for consumers like us to spend. I don't mind spending, but treat me like you would expect to be treated at the Mecca of gambling. I plan on writing them a letter and telling all what happened to me.

Jun 13 2009 	A bit of ancient rome in the middle of Vegas	Once again it was time for me to head out to Vegas for a little relaxation and for this trip I chose to stay at Caesars Palace due to the fabulous rate I received for the Memorial Day holiday weekend. I wasnt expecting it to be too crowded due to all the economic reviews Ive been hearing, but I was sorely mistaken. Valet parking was PACKED when I arrived at 10PM and it was closed to all but Diamond and Seven Star members. I remembered there was valet parking in back by the parking garage and headed back there. No crowds and I zipped right in. The downside is the long walk to registration.When I arrived at the front desk there were only a couple of people ahead of me and it gave me time to figure out if I wanted to give the $20 bribe a shot. I was undecided and I always wonder if Id come off looking like a fool. I waited till the last moment and decided the heck with it. The clerk was real friendly and he informed that as a Platinum member I could have stood in a quicker line (which actually wasnt moving so quickly). As of April 1, 2009 I was no longer a Platinum member and had been busted back down to Gold due to my lack of gambling over the past 15 months. My online Harrahs account has me listed as a Gold member, but my reservation had me pegged as a Platinum member  go figure <shrug>. It all worked to my benefit because he upgraded me to the 25th floor in the Palace Tower. Granted its NOT the nicest tower, but it was close to the pool and I had a half-way decent view of the strip. The walk to the Palace Tower from the front desk is a bit of a hike, but its not too horrible. I arrived at my room and was pleasantly surprised  the room had been recently updated (1+ year or so), decent sized, and the dcor was modern with a touch of class. The rooms most unique feature is its dual marble bathroom, united by a walk-in shower and featuring an oversized spa tub. The room was clean upon my arrival and throughout my stay. The room came with the following amenities: LDC Television, bedside clock radio with CD player, & MP-3 hook-up, Gilchrest & Soames bath amenities, wet/dry mini bar, 2 waffle weave robes, and an in-room safe. One thing I did want to comment about was the great job the maids did in keeping everything clean because many of the hotel guests did their best to trash the place. Each day the hallway was spotless, but by the next morning people had trashed it. Garbage thrown on the floor, cigarette butts snubbed out on the wall and flicked to the floor, not to mention the amount of empty beer bottles tossed about. People, I realize youre on vacation, but does that mean you have to act like a bunch of slobs???Off my soap boxAs you can see from my pictures, there is a great deal of construction going on around the pool area which was a bit problemsome. I didnt find the noise to be an issue, but the lack of chairs was a problem. Im not sure if this is always an issue, but 15-20 minutes after the pool opened, all the chairs were taken. For the next few hours all you see are people walking around searching for a chair. During my stay, the hotel was extremely rigid in regards to when the pool opened. People were not allowed out into the pool area until 9:00 AM on the dot. Therefore, that meant people started forming a line at 8:30 AM. A word to the wise, forget about grabbing a towel right away. Go grab your chair and then head back to get a towel after most people have gone through the line or otherwise youll miss out on the prime real estate around the pool. Drink service was so so  I chose instead to walk up to the tiki bar and grab a brew rather than waiting for the waitress to come back around. The wait staff was working hard, they just couldn't keep up with all the demand.All in all I had a nice trip and would recommend Caesars Palace to many of my friends. Its centrally located, nice pool area (when the construction is completed), nice restaurant and a large gaming area. Enjoy!!

May 28 2009 	Nice Place	I recently returned to Las Vegas for a business trip, and luckily stayed at Caesar's Palace. Check-in was quick, as I checked-in around 9 pm and there was not a line. The place is huge, so it took a bit to find the elevator bank leading to my room. I stayed in the Forum Tower and had a really nice room. It was pretty big, clean, had a large flat screen Sony TV in the bedroom and a tv built into the bathroom mirror. The A/C worked great, but I didn't have much of a view. I checked out around noon, and there was a 15 minute line. There are several dining options in the hotel. In particular, I ate at Mesa Grill which is reasonably priced and offers very good food. May 26 2009	Avoid this hotel -- nothing but problems that the staff refuses to fix	I've been to Vegas hundreds of times. I've been going 2-4 times a year since I was a baby. This was the worst trip I've ever had, and it was all thanks to Caesar's Palace. My family had stayed there before about 4-5 years ago and we decided to stay there again this year b/c of a deal the hotel offered and b/c we wanted to take advantage of their nice pool area.We requested a room next to a family member's room. This was arranged months in advance, but when we got there we got moved from a room in the new, modern Augustus Tower to the completely out-dated, old-fashioned, poorly-furnished, horribly dark and dingy Roman Tower. They said our original room wasn't ready. When we complained we were told we had to pay for an upgrade even though they downgraded us without any notice at all! The room was facing another tower, the beds were smaller than any beds I slept in in European budget hotels (European hotels have smaller beds than American hotels, I have learned. Caesar's is the exception.) There was ZERO sunlight that entered the room, despite it being the beginning of a sunny, hot Vegas summer. There was only one light in the room and it took a lot of work to get it to function. The bathroom was remodeled, but only one of its 3 lights were functioning, making it very difficult to get ready in there. Everything was dirty, dark, and dingy. I should also mention at check-in that they said we had an envelope at another desk, but that desk said they didn't and treated us like we were crazy for asking. Two hours before checking out, we get a phone call that they had a gift card waiting for us. The gift card was for the hotel so we couldn't even use it! And it was a gift from a friend. What a waste!We tried getting out of the room and hanging out by the pool, but half the seats are reserved (pool guy told me you need to spend a half million before they can reserve seats for you). The pool chairs are all stacked in tight rows so you can't distance yourself from any other groups. This isn't a problem though since it's impossible to find any seats together. I got 4 seats b/c i went really early, but when I got out of the water I found that the pool guys had given my chairs to another group of people even though I had a beach bag, clothes, hats, magazines, and sunscreen covering them. Also, there was construction, and dust and debris got in the water and on my bathing suit. So now the room stunk and the pool stunk, so we went to the casino which was virtually empty. The lounges are all very dull and the only one that ever gets a crowd is the Shadow Bar. However, this may only be because it's so small 10 people constitute a crowd. There's no live music or any other kind of entertainment to enjoy while you drink or gamble. Also, the waitresses that worked the casino were very slow. I attribute this to the fact that they were understaffed and had to much ground to cover to work speedily and efficiently.The bellmen also were very slow. We waited over 30 min for one when we were checking out. They were severely understaffed, leading to delays and REALLY long lines at the bell desk.Also, don't expect extra towels, toiletries, or anything else because even if you request them and they say they'll send someone up they never do.Please avoid Caesar's Palace. It has gone down hill, the staff at the check-in/check-out desks are rude and unhelpful, and all the other areas of the hotel are understaffed. Instead, stay at Paris, Las Vegas. The rooms are much nicer, and if you don't get a remodeled room, the older rooms are a million times better than those at Caesar's.Caesar's will never see me or any of my friends and family again.

May 22 2009 	Enjoyed our stay here very much	This is now the third time that we have stayed in Caesars Palace so you can see that we do like it. I feel that I should now give feedback to counteract some of the negative comments that others have left (although I do not dispute that they received poor service.) The receptionist said that the room we had been allocated was in that tower anyway! I felt that we got a fantastic deal - the room had 2 interconnecting bathrooms, was beautifully furnished and was spotlessly clean. The hotel is big and impersonal but so are many of the other hotels in Las Vegas. We also toured around Arizona and for our last night returned to Las Vegas as we were flying out the following morning. This time I booked on the Caesars Palace website and got a deal for a hotel room and 2 tickets for Elton John. This time the room was in the newly refurbished Forum Tower and it was very nice as well, although I still prefer the Palace Tower. This room was convenient for the show as it is just across the Forum Casino from the theatre. Would I stay here again if I went to Las Vegas? The only disappointment was that the swimming pools closed early so don't leave it too late if you want to go for a swim!!

The room was filthy. The bedding was dirty, the couch full of stains and looked like it was 30 years old. The carpet wasn't even vacuumed. There was food and nuts laying on the carpet. The aircon was unbearably noisy. We switched room when I complained about the filth and aircon. The new room was marginally better, but the bedding and furniture was still dirty (I got extra blankets to sit on the couch as it looked terrible). Then it got worse. We called 3 times with no one coming to fix it after many promises. Eventually, I told housekeeping that we had to leave to a show but that they should sort it out as it was now running onto the carpet. They assured us they would sort it out asap. When we came back to the room about 4 hours later, the whole carpet was flooded and the outside corridor was also flooded. They did however fix the plumbing. They simply left towels on the carpet in the room which were by then sopping wet. They didn't bother to move us or even make the offer to move us. I mean come on, how can you leave the room looking like that when your plumbing is busted. We checked out the next day. However, if you dine at the cafe in the main lobby, don't go for the surf 'n turf as I had to send mine back. I've had leather shoes softer than the steak! Concert was frikkin AMAZING...with two of the best seats in the house! Returning to Vegas in July, but still on the fence about where to stay. Caesar's is a sure bet...but have thought about trying out the other Harrah properties.

May 19 2009 	Gone down hill	I have stayed here several times before and have always felt it was about average for what they charge. It is an older property so its age is evident in many places. This time was one disaster after another. First we reserved this six months in advance as I was a speaker at a conference being held in the hotel. They immediatly charged my room when we placed the reservation as I recieved a receipt--that was alittle strange since normally it is a reservation and not a room purchase. Any way, several months later my bookkeeper notifies me we have another charge for the same room. They had charged twice. I had my staff get with them and finally we were ablke to get a credit issued before I arrived at the hotel. I had a long drive from a client location in California to Las Vegas so I get in at 10. My staff had reassured me it was a non-smoking king which is what they always order. After going through the pain of crossing through the casino to register (what a hassle but normal in these hotels) I get my key and we head back across the casino to the room in one of the towers. As soon as I open the room I could smell the stench of cigarette smoke. We wlak in and it looks like someone had laid on the bed and there were three cigarette butts in an ash tray. We were in a smoking room that was dirty (someone had removed all the amenities in the bathroom) so they must have come up after the room was cleaned and conducted their business on the phone while chain smoking and took all the amenities on their way out. We called the front desk. We were placed on hold for the longest period of time. They told us they would have someone look into it and call us back. Half an hour later we are still sitting in that stinking room. We call again--and again placed on hold. Finally we are able to speak to a human and they said they had no more available non-smoking rooms. We insisted. They finally found one in a different tower. They instructed us to meet someone over there. When we arrived we were surprised that the guard arrived only minutes after we did since we had expected to wait forever. He said he could let us in but had no keys for us and told us we would have to go all the way back to the front desk to get our keys. What a disappointment but it was now becoming par for this experience. We head into our room which was clean. We wanted to order two ice teas and a piece of cake since we had now been there for an hour. When we called, room service told us it would be another hour before they could have the two teas and piece of cake delivered--see a pattern here. It finally showed up and we got to bed around moidnight with the hopes the next day would be better. I called my staff the next day and told them of the situation and fiasco. My travel coordinator told me he was on the phone with the management and they would send up two keys. I decied to order room service. I was told it would take an hour and a half. Surprised??? Now what--do I wait a long time for my meal or a long time for my keys to be delivered. Finally my coordinator was able to reach someone at Caesars that seemed to care. They gave me a complaint number to dial. She apologized and comped the room. I stressed the poor service and slow service as a systemic issue. Apparently the slow room service is a staffing issue but I believe it, along with the other issues here, reflects poorly on Caesars Palace..

May 19 2009	Not cheap but worth it	Huge, huge, huge! Everything is big! the hotel is really nice and my room was big and super comfortable with a jacuzzi, overlooking the strip. It wasn't cheap but for one night it's perfect!

May 15 2009 	Disappointed	I've stayed at Caesar's before and I've always had a decent experience, at least no memorable complaints. A group of 14 of us stayed there last month for a bachelorette party and we just could not believe the terrible service we received. To preface--the bachelorette's mother did the booking and is a regular Caesar's visitor. Upon check-in (at the player's club VIP check-in nonetheless) she was told they were completely booked and the 3 rooms for our party (mom and friend had their own) would be spread out on several floors, unacceptable for a reservation made weeks before. An hour later (at 11p) they finally figured out they could get us a suite in the older tower with 3 rooms adjoining. However the adjoining rooms only had 1 king bed each so we needed 4-5 rollaways to sleep the remaining girls (12 total). Fine, actually it was quite nice when we got there, if a little cheesy. It was definitely older but it had a bar setup and extra bathrooms, which was great for the number of females in close quarters. We were easily satisfied and got to partying. None of the keys worked for the adjoining rooms (the suite itself was really just a massive living room/bar, no beds).A while later "Charles" showed up with our rollaways, 2 of them! We told him we needed several more, AND we needed someone to open up the adjoining rooms. He was very rude, told us he couldn't bring more and couldn't open the rooms. Mind you we'd been there over an hour already and had made the call for service right when we got there. After some coaxing we got him to bring a few more rollaways and open the rooms, when one of our nicer friends went to thank him--was actually even going to tip him after that service!--he walked off in a huff and say "yeah whatever". That was probably the worst of the service we got all weekend, but it was within several hours of arrival so we were even more keen to the crappy stuff that went on the rest of the weekend.Our room was never cleaned unless we asked--we literally had to ask for them to bring up more toilet paper after no one showed up to the room for the first 36 hours and the bathrooms/rooms/suite itself were never actually cleaned, just new towels and toiletries brought. They never got rid of the room service carts, at one point we wheeled out a dirty cart into the hall because we didn't want to see/smell the old food anymore and it sat in the hall in front of our door for 24 hours! Oh, and I had a burnt/tasteless burger at Augustus Cafe that was one of the worst burgers I've ever had, let alone it was $18! I am far from a food complainer, I eat everything and it's especially hard to screw up a burger but it was literally flavorless meat, charred to a crisp (the edges were actually shriveled hard and black).One highlight, we got the BEST server ever at the sushi place, Hyakumi, on our last dinner. She remembered everyone's name in a party of 10, was super helpful, sweet and attentive. We wrote her a glowing comment card (and big tip) but when we asked to speak to the manager to tell her how amazing our server was, she said she was busy and would be right with us...and continued to walk back and forth in front of us several more times saying "just a minute", we finally just left after we realized she probably wasn't going to stop. Maybe if the managerial staff at Caesar's spent just a little more time praising good work, the staff would have more motivation to actually BE good.Overall, I know our collective bad experiences were probably just unfortunate conicidences judging by all the other comments--and like I said I've stayed before and they were pretty okay (I'm really not just a complainer, I mainly just write good reviews on here). But for the price you pay, and all the other great choices in Vegas, you would hope they would go that extra mile.

May 15 2009 	Excellent Hotel + free Upgrade! Apr 13 2009 	Great Stay As Always!	We stayed at Caesar's for three days, Thursday through Sunday. It was busy, as it was a holiday weekend, but even so we had a great stay. Apr 8 2009 	We lived like rockstars	My friends and I stayed March16-20 for our spring break. We are all 21 and love to gamble. Apparently, this is not the case at Ceasers. We could smell cigarette smoke in our room...not stale, left-over, from a previous guest smoke, but like next door smoke coming through the vent or something. There are four boxes sitting on the dresser: chips, peanuts, cashews, poppycock and a Romance Package. There is no visible sign telling you this--the bellhop didn't tell us this--the front desk didn't tell us this--nor did the group we were with told us this, but if you even remove any of these boxes, you are charged for it. How do they know? There are sensors under them. Luckily, we called to find out what the deal was and if we were in fact charged for the things we touched, but didn't use. You have 30 seconds to look at it and put it back before you are charged. A small, single serve bag of Poppycock, nicely packaged in a fancy box was $10. Outrageous are the prices of this hotel! You pay big money for the rooms, which are nice, and then are so strengent about every little thing. There is no coffee pot in the room and if you use room service, be prepared to pay by the pot; $20. Don't order a soft drink, it's $4, but in the machine you can get it for $2.50. I wasn't impressed with the Shops at the Forum compared to the ones in some of the other hotel shops. I brought my computer so I could go online and research transportation and shows, etc. I could only get online with the hotel WiFi for $15. WIth the prices of everything else, they should provide this. Also, the ironing board stunk! No padding and very hard to iron on. They have a swimming pool, but there was so much construction, the jack hammers made laying by the pool impossible. I probably wouldn't stay here again.

Mar 31 2009 	Poor service - unfortunate	Location is central though the sheer length of the Strip and the frequent construction/road works/congestion on Las Vegas Blvd means it might not necessarily help much - you should buffer ample time to drive out of the Strip or to other resorts towards the ends of the Strip (for shows that start on time). Rooms are decent but probably overrated. We were told ours would be a 'nice room' for honeymooners in the recently refurbished Forum Tower - while it is well-maintained and modernly furnished it had a poor blocked view and nothing to shout about. You would probably have to upgrade to get a themed room. The show stopper here is really the very curt service and indifferent staff who will not hesitate to say no and treat you like yet another guest passing through. Calls to guest relations/housekeeping/room service took 3-5min before they were answered; check-in/out queues were long and processed by unfriendly staff; and more often than not deliveries to the room took longer than half an hour, once never arriving despite repeated, futile reminder calls. The person on the line even said it was barely 3min since our last call (it was more like 10-15min) and promised that the shower cap requested would arrive if we waited - which did not happen! In the end my wife waited over an hour for nothing and that really ate into our rest time. The feeling came close to silent suffering..! I would guess that the hotel might be understaffed/overworked... Apart from the iconic theme and decor around the hotel, we have to give a thumbs-down - this is arguably the worst out of the 4 hotels we stayed in over the course of our holiday. Come with no expectations, or prepare to be badly disappointed.

Mar 29 2009 	A ghost of its past	Coasting on a very yesteryear Las Vegas reputation, this now soulless edifice is like a ride at Disneyland that's had its day. Though the rooms are clean and comfortable provided one stays in only one of three towers Augustus,Palace or Forum (forget the rest-they are junk rooms) this once great casino is ludicrously overpriced for every little thing. ($14.95 for internet service for 24 hours, room charge of $8 for a slice of toast and a cup of coffee plus a $5.00 room charge plus 18% gratuity...etc) It is now only worth a quick walk through to ogle at the over the top excesses in decoration. Restaurants on the whole have become mediocre with only perhaps Bradley Ogden as the lone standout. Guy Savoy has a restaurant there where the set menu is $290.00 per person which in this economy sounds a tad over the top. Forget playing there as every machine and table game is outfitted with terrible odds stacked against you. In its day Caesar's Palace had charm in its gaudiness and its atmosphere was exciting. Now it is just aggressively tacky. As an example I wanted to purchase a local newspaper in one of the gift shops only to be told that none carry the local paper anymore. When I asked why, the lady behind the counter told me she had heard that management didn't want their customers to read about the much better and more reasonable offers that were to be had elsewhere in terms of food and entertainment. One can get a much better experience for the same or less money on the strip at Wynn's,The Venetian or the Palazzo where true luxury reigns as opposed to the ersatz luxury of Caesar's Palace.

Mar 28 2009 	We would stay here again	We booked a 3 night stay from Tuesday to Friday, between March Madness games. We were able to get an amazing rate using a promo code tip from the Fatwallet forums at $75 a night for a Classic Room. I had read plenty of reviews saying that these rooms were horrible, but we never found out. We asked for an upgrade at the desk, received a Palace Tower room at no extra charge and tipped the clerk $20! The Palace Tower room was great for us, lots of space to spread out, which is a real luxury compared to your standard hotel rooms. The bathroom had two sinks, a separate shower and a jetted tub. Even though the elevators for this room seem to be a mile away from the strip, it was nice to step off the elevator and be right at the pool area.We lounged by the pool 3 of the 4 days we were there. Lots of construction going on, but definitely a nice pool area. My only complaint may be that the drink and food service poolside was spotty at best...there was only one girl working the pool....just too many people for one person to serve.We wandered the hotel and saw the casino area and all the shops, which was impressive, but I can shop at home and we are pretty low-rollers, so we gambled elsewhere. We joined the Players Club which got us two $20 meal vouchers for the buffet. We ate there for breakfast one morning. My husband thought it was amazing, I thought it was fine. I don't know if it would be my choice if we were paying for it, but for free it was great. Great location, centered on the strip. We would definitely stay here again, especially if we could get such a great rate again.
